abstract: Federal and state tests link oil spill in Puget Sound, which fouled 20 miles of beaches in Oct, to ConocoPhillips tanker; company denial (S)
snippet: Federal and state tests link oil spill in Puget Sound, which fouled 20 miles of beaches in Oct, to ConocoPhillips tanker; company denial (S)
lead_paragraph: The source of more than 1,000 gallons of oil that spilled into Puget Sound in the early morning of Oct. 14, fouling 20 miles of beaches, appears to have been discovered. Tests by federal and state laboratories found that the oil's "fingerprint" connected it to a tanker owned by ConocoPhillips of Houston, Gov. Gary Locke and Rear Adm. Jeffrey Garrett of the Coast Guard said in a joint statement. A company spokeswoman, Lara Dilley, said, "We do not believe we are the responsible party based on all the information we have to date." Eli Sanders (NYT)

abstract: Punishing winds and mammoth swells shoved the freighter Selendang Ayu hard ashore in the Aleutian Islands in Alaska two weeks ago, cracking the ship in two, leading to the deaths of six crewmen and setting off an oil spill originally estimated at more than 40,000 gallons.     Now the Bering Sea's harsh weather has sharply tilted the bow half of the freighter and almost fully sank it late last week in a swirl of 35-mile-an-hour winds, 16-foot waves and blowing snow. In the process up to 316,000 additional gallons of oil are thought to have spilled.

abstract: Second breached fuel tank is found in wreckage of freighter Selendang Ayu, which ran aground and broke in Aleutian Islands; 40,000 gallons of fuel have leaked near sensitive wildlife refuge and new breach raises possibility that more than 100,000 gallons could leak (S)
snippet: Second breached fuel tank is found in wreckage of freighter Selendang Ayu, which ran aground and broke in Aleutian Islands; 40,000 gallons of fuel have leaked near sensitive wildlife refuge and new breach raises possibility that more than 100,000 ...
lead_paragraph: A second breached fuel tank was discovered in the wreckage of the freighter Selendang Ayu, which ran aground and broke in two last week in the Aleutian Islands. Marti Early, spokeswoman for the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation, said the breach was discovered when a break in the weather allowed closer inspection of the vessel, which has been spilling oil near a sensitive wildlife refuge. More than 40,000 gallons of fuel have leaked from the freighter, Ms. Early said, and the newly discovered breach raised the possibility that more than 100,000 more gallons could leak. Eli Sanders (NYT)

And if the auction takes place, the winner most likely will be a financially opaque, government-run natural gas behemoth, Gazprom.

abstract: Controlling shareholders in Russian oil giant Yukos warn they might sue ultimate buyer of its subsidiary, Yuganskneftegas, as well as lenders who help finance winning bid; Tim Osborne, director for Group Menatep, which is based in London and is holding company for investments of Yukos's founder, Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, says Russian government is knowingly expropriating assets (S)
snippet: Controlling shareholders in Russian oil giant Yukos warn they might sue ultimate buyer of its subsidiary, Yuganskneftegas, as well as lenders who help finance winning bid; Tim Osborne, director for Group Menatep, which is based in London and is ho...
lead_paragraph: The controlling shareholders in the Russian oil giant Yukos warned that they might sue the ultimate buyer of its subsidiary, Yuganskneftegas, as well as lenders who help finance the winning bid. Tim Osborne, a director for Group Menatep, which is based in London and is the holding company for the investments of Yukos's founder, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, said "the Russian government is knowingly expropriating assets, thereby Gazprom or whomever buys and finances the auction, including the banks, benefit from illegal expropriation." Mr. Osborne said Group Menatep reserved the right to sue in any jurisdiction and to seize Gazprom assets. "Conceivably oil tankers could be seized as protection against future damage awards," he said. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

abstract: Overseas Shipholding Group acquires Stelmar Shipping for about $843 million to exdpand its fleet at time when shipbuilders are booked years in advance (S)
snippet: Overseas Shipholding Group acquires Stelmar Shipping for about $843 million to exdpand its fleet at time when shipbuilders are booked years in advance (S)
lead_paragraph: Overseas Shipholding Group has agreed to buy Stelmar Shipping for about $843 million to expand its fleet at a time when shipbuilders are booked years in advance. Overseas Shipholding, based in New York, will pay $48 a share in cash, an 8.3 percent premium to Stelmar's closing price last Friday, and will assume $457 million in debt, Stelmar said yesterday. Two previous offers for Stelmar failed. One, from the OMI Corporation, was rejected by company management, and the most recent, a $703 million bid from Fortress Investment Group, was opposed by Stelmar's biggest shareholder, Stelios Haji-Ioannou, founder of EasyJet, as being too low. "I have no misgivings about the process this time," Mr. Haji-Ioannou said in a statement posted on his Web site. The offer still must be approved by Stelmar shareholders. Stelmar is based in Athens.

abstract: Coast Guard says 15-foot-long U-shaped pipe lying on bottom of Delaware River was cause of oil spill from tanker Athos I; photo (S)
snippet: Coast Guard says 15-foot-long U-shaped pipe lying on bottom of Delaware River was cause of oil spill from tanker Athos I; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: An oil spill from a tanker that will take months and millions of dollars to clean up was apparently caused by an iron pipe at the bottom of the Delaware River, the United States Coast Guard said. The Nov. 26 spill, involving tens of thousands of gallons of oil, killed birds and other wildlife, slowed shipping and fouled 85 miles of shoreline in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware. Investigators said they did not know where the 15-foot-long U-shaped pipe came from, but that it was found in the path of the tanker, the Athos I, and that paint from the pipe matched samples taken from the tanker's hull, said Capt. Jonathan D. Sarubbi of the Port of Philadelphia. Jason George

abstract: Japan's current account surplus declined seasonally adjusted 9.1 percent in October from September as higher oil prices increased value of imports while export growth slowed; surplus fell to 1.36 trillion yen ($13 billion) from 1.5 trillion yen in September; exports rose 0.9 percent from month earlier, to 4.97 trillion yen, while imports gained 3.2 percent, to 3.93 trillion yen (S)
snippet: Japan's current account surplus declined seasonally adjusted 9.1 percent in October from September as higher oil prices increased value of imports while export growth slowed; surplus fell to 1.36 trillion yen ($13 billion) from 1.5 trillion yen in...
lead_paragraph: Japan's current account surplus declined a seasonally adjusted 9.1 percent in October from September as higher oil prices increased the value of imports while export growth slowed. The surplus fell to 1.36 trillion yen ($13 billion) from 1.5 trillion yen in September, a Ministry of Finance report said. That was lower than economists had expected for the surplus, which shrank for the second consecutive month. Exports rose 0.9 percent from a month earlier, to 4.97 trillion yen, while imports gained 3.2 percent, to 3.93 trillion yen. Slowing export growth is a concern for Japan because the current recovery has been largely driven by exports. Also, orders for machinery unexpectedly fell in October, declining a seasonally adjusted 3.1 percent from the month before. Todd Zaun (NYT)

Kevin Bell, like others who were on the scene of the monster Exxon Valdez oil spill in Prince William Sound, can still remember it all in haunting detail, 15 years later: the pungent smell, the dead sea otters coated in oil, the thousands of dead birds scooped from the slick black waters and stuffed into plastic garbage bags on the decks of his research vessel.

abstract: United States Coast Guard says Athos I tanker oil spill that emptied thousands of gallons of oil into Delaware River was caused by pipe found in path of tanker (S)
snippet: United States Coast Guard says Athos I tanker oil spill that emptied thousands of gallons of oil into Delaware River was caused by pipe found in path of tanker (S)
lead_paragraph: An oil spill from a tanker that will take months and millions of dollars to clean up was apparently caused by an iron pipe at the bottom of the Delaware River, the United States Coast Guard said yesterday. The Nov. 26 spill, involving tens of thousands of gallons of oil, killed birds and other wildlife, slowed shipping and fouled 85 miles of shoreline in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware. Investigators said they did not know where the 15-foot-long U-shaped pipe came from, but that it was found in the path of the tanker, the Athos I, and that paint from the pipe matched samples taken from the tanker's hull, said Capt. Jonathan D. Sarubbi of the Port of Philadelphia. Jason George (NYT)

abstract: Yuganskneftegaz, largest subsidiary of Russian oil company Yukos, is hit with another back tax claim just weeks before unit is scheduled to be put up for auction; subsidiary receives back tax bill for additional 34 billion rubles ($1.2 billion) for year 2003 (S)
snippet: Yuganskneftegaz, largest subsidiary of Russian oil company Yukos, is hit with another back tax claim just weeks before unit is scheduled to be put up for auction; subsidiary receives back tax bill for additional 34 billion rubles ($1.2 billion) fo...
lead_paragraph: The largest subsidiary of the Russian oil company Yukos has been hit with another back tax claim just weeks before the unit was scheduled to be put up for auction. Yukos said the subsidiary, Yuganskneftegaz, received a back tax bill for an additional 34 billion rubles ($1.2 billion) for the year 2003. Tax claims against Yuganskneftegaz exceed 140 billion rubles ($5 billion). The entire tax debt for Yukos totals 735.7 billion rubles ($26.3 billion), more than the company's estimated value. The Federal Property Fund of Russia scheduled an auction for 76.79 percent of Yuganskneftegaz for Dec. 19 with a starting price of 246.75 billion rubles ($8.84 billion). Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

abstract: Alaska officials, facing warming trend that has halved frozen season when oil exploration can occur, say they have settled on new way to decide when tundra of North Slope is hard enough to withstand convoys of heavy vehicles (S)i
snippet: Alaska officials, facing warming trend that has halved frozen season when oil exploration can occur, say they have settled on new way to decide when tundra of North Slope is hard enough to withstand convoys of heavy vehicles (S)i
lead_paragraph: Facing a warming trend that has halved the frozen season when oil exploration can occur, state officials said they had settled on a new way to decide when the tundra of the North Slope was hard enough to withstand convoys of heavy vehicles. Gov. Frank H. Murkowski, a Republican, said tests last winter showed the exploration season could be lengthened without environmental damage. But ecologists said that the tests were rushed and not adequately reviewed by independent experts and that warming should prompt a more cautious approach, not slimmer margins of error. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

abstract: Port of Philadelphia restrict ships with hull that extend more than 34 feet below surface from traveling Delaware River at any time except high tide; order follows leak of substantially more than 30,000 gallons of oil from tanker Athos 1 (S)
snippet: Port of Philadelphia restrict ships with hull that extend more than 34 feet below surface from traveling Delaware River at any time except high tide; order follows leak of substantially more than 30,000 gallons of oil from tanker Athos 1 (S)
lead_paragraph: Officials at the Port of Philadelphia have imposed restrictions on ship traffic on the Delaware River as they investigate what punctured an oil tanker's hull. Officials initially estimated that 30,000 gallons had leaked from the tanker, Athos I, but last Tuesday, they said it was a "substantially higher amount." The spill has extended for about 55 miles, according to a United States Coast Guard spokesman. The new restriction prohibits ships whose hulls extend more than 34 feet below the water from traveling in the river's channel at any time except during high tide. Jason George

abstract: Oil prices have been at record highs this year, with money flowing into the coffers of oil producers thanks to the world's growing thirst for oil. But as OPEC leaders head into a fifth and final meeting this year on Friday, the topic on their minds and on the agenda is whether the world will have too much oil next year. For some, production cuts may be in order.     After hitting a record of more than $55 a barrel in October, oil prices in New York have since fallen by 23 percent. Under pressure to bring down oil prices, OPEC's members began pumping at full capacity this summer and continue to do so.

abstract: Law enforcement officers from Nefteyugansk reportedly raid Yukos' Siberian subsidiary Yuganskneftegas and seize documents; Pres Vladimir Putin, during visit to India, says Russia would welcome bid by companies in India to buy assets of Yuganskneftegas, which are to be auctioned on December 19; photo (S)
snippet: Law enforcement officers from Nefteyugansk reportedly raid Yukos' Siberian subsidiary Yuganskneftegas and seize documents; Pres Vladimir Putin, during visit to India, says Russia would welcome bid by companies in India to buy assets of Yuganskneft...
lead_paragraph: A Sibe-rian subsidiary of the Russian oil company Yukos has been searched by law enforcement officers from the western Siberian city of Nefteyugansk, a company official told the Interfax news agency. The enforcement officers seized documents from the subsidiary, Yuganskneftegas, Interfax reported. Yukos offices in Moscow and at other subsidiaries have been raided repeatedly over the last year in connection with federal prosecutors' investigation into government claims for more than $24 billion in back taxes owed by the oil giant. Russian President Vladimir V. Putin, on a three-day visit to India, said the Russian government would welcome a bid by companies in India to buy assets of Yuganskneftegas. A 77 percent stake in the subsidiary is to be auctioned on Dec. 19 to help Yukos pay back taxes. The Indian oil minister, Mani Shankar Aiyar, above, said Mr. Putin "welcomed bids by Indian firms, either on their own or in collaboration with Russian firms," Reuters reported. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

abstract: Ship whose hulls extend 34 feet or more below surface are barred from Delaware River except at high tide following oil leak from tanker Athos I; Coast Guard probes whether tanker's hull was punctured by propeller that fell from dredger in April (S)
snippet: Ship whose hulls extend 34 feet or more below surface are barred from Delaware River except at high tide following oil leak from tanker Athos I; Coast Guard probes whether tanker's hull was punctured by propeller that fell from dredger in April (S...
lead_paragraph: Officials at the Port of Philadelphia imposed restrictions yesterday on ship traffic on the Delaware River as they continued to investigate what punctured an oil tanker's hull last week. Officials initially estimated that 30,000 gallons had leaked out from the tanker, the Athos I, six days ago, but on Tuesday, they said it was a "substantially higher amount." By yesterday, the spill extended for about 55 miles, according to a United States Coast Guard spokesman. The new restriction, which prohibits ships whose hulls extend more than 34 feet below the water from traveling in the river's channel at any time except during high tide, was put in place as port and Coast Guard officials tried to determine whether a missing 14-foot-long propeller, which fell off a dredger in April, may have punctured the hull. Jason George (NYT)

snippet: China Aviation Oil (Singapore) Corp reportedly will ask Singapore High Court for protection from creditors after losing about $550 million in oil market; suspends its chief executive and is negotiating rescue by Chinese parent, China Aviation Oil ...
lead_paragraph: The China Aviation Oil (Singapore) Corporation, supplier of one-third of China's jet fuel, will ask Singapore's High Court for protection from creditors after losing about $550 million in the oil market. The company said it had suspended its chief executive and was negotiating a rescue by its Chinese parent company and Temasek Holdings, Singapore's state investment agency. The parent company, China Aviation Oil Holding Company in Beijing, and Temasek may each invest $50 million, the company said. The company will propose a plan to creditors to pay debts and will ask the High Court of Singapore to fix a date to meet with creditors, the statement said.

abstract: Researchers at a government nuclear laboratory and a ceramics company in Salt Lake City say they have found a way to produce pure hydrogen with far less energy than other methods, raising the possibility of using nuclear power to indirectly wean the transportation system from its dependence on oil.    The development would move the country closer to the Energy Department's goal of a ''hydrogen economy,'' in which hydrogen would be created through a variety of means, and would be consumed by devices called fuel cells, to make electricity to run cars and for other purposes. Experts cite three big roadblocks to a hydrogen economy: manufacturing hydrogen cleanly and at low cost, finding a way to ship it and store it on the vehicles that use it, and reducing the astronomical price of fuel cells.

abstract: Long Island Power Authority expects no rate increases for its electricity customers through 2005, despite fluctuations in prices for oil and gas that fuel its generators (S)
snippet: Long Island Power Authority expects no rate increases for its electricity customers through 2005, despite fluctuations in prices for oil and gas that fuel its generators (S)
lead_paragraph: Despite fluctuations in prices for the oil and gas that fuel its generators, the Long Island Power Authority expects no rate increases for its electricity customers through next year. Barring an unforeseen "worldwide energy crisis," rates will be frozen for 2005 and are likely to stay stable the next few years, the power authority's chairman, Richard M. Kessel, said yesterday as he proposed a $3 billion budget. "We're one of a handful of utilities in the nation that is not increasing customers' bills," he said. Instead, the authority is cutting expenses and absorbing fuel costs. The Long Island Power Authority serves nearly three million people in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and the Rockaways in Queens. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

abstract: Police officials reduce speed limit to 30 mph from 45 on small stretch of Route 9A in Briarcliff Manor, NY, where gasoline tanker flipped over in fiery crash (S)
snippet: Police officials reduce speed limit to 30 mph from 45 on small stretch of Route 9A in Briarcliff Manor, NY, where gasoline tanker flipped over in fiery crash (S)
lead_paragraph: Police officials yesterday indefinitely reduced the speed limit to 30 miles an hour from 45 along a small stretch of Route 9A in Westchester County where a gasoline tanker flipped over in a fiery crash Wednesday night. Investigators were still trying to determine the cause. The accident triggered a large fireball around 7:35 p.m. near the Pleasantville Road overpass. The driver of the 4,700-gallon tanker, Henry Tulloch of Brooklyn, was being treated for burns at Westchester Medical Center and was listed as stable. A small car also became engulfed in flames, but the Briarcliff Manor police chief, Norman Campion, said he was uncertain whether the vehicles had collided. The car's driver, Stacey Morales-Bradley, of Peekskill, who suffered burns, was also listed in stable condition. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

abstract: Stelmar Shipping says chief executive officer Stamatis Molaris has resigned, citing personal attacks against him in connection with failed takeover attempt by Fortress Investment Group; Stelmar's founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou led opposition to $703 million offer, which has been rejected by shareholders (S)
snippet: Stelmar Shipping says chief executive officer Stamatis Molaris has resigned, citing personal attacks against him in connection with failed takeover attempt by Fortress Investment Group; Stelmar's founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou led opposition to $703...
lead_paragraph: Stelmar Shipping, owner of one of the world's largest tanker fleets for oil products, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Stamatis Molaris, had resigned, citing personal attacks against him in connection with a failed takeover attempt by the Fortress Investment Group. Stelios Haji-Ioannou, Stelmar's founder and largest shareholder, led opposition to the $703 million offer, which was rejected by shareholders on Tuesday. Mr. Haji-Ioannou demanded the dismissal of Mr. Molaris and the chief executive, Peter Goodfellow, as a condition of his joining the board to lead a new search for a buyer, Stelmar said yesterday. A panel of four independent directors rejected the demand, and Mr. Molaris subsequently resigned, the company said. Stelmar, which is based in Athens, said it intended to reopen the auction and will accept new buyout proposals. Fortress, based in New York, bid $40 a share for Stelmar.

headline.main: STELMAR EXECUTIVE RESIGNS AFTER FAILED BID

abstract: British-Russian oil company TNK-BP gets Russian back-tax bill of $87 million, not including penalties; company expects overall tax bill of $6.5 billion for 2004 (S)
snippet: British-Russian oil company TNK-BP gets Russian back-tax bill of $87 million, not including penalties; company expects overall tax bill of $6.5 billion for 2004 (S)
lead_paragraph: A British-Russian oil company, TNK-BP, received a back-tax bill for 2001 totaling 2.5 billion rubles ($87 million), not including possible penalties and interest payments, a spokeswoman confirmed. The spokeswoman, Marina Dracheva, said the company was contesting the tax claim, which stemmed from a routine check by tax authorities. "Our intent is to consult with relevant tax authorities to regulate the matter to mutual satisfaction," she said. The claim is small compared with the company's overall tax bill; TNK-BP expects a tax bill of $6.5 billion for 2004, consistent with Russia's 24 percent rate on corporate profits, Ms. Dracheva said. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

abstract: Japan's current-account surplus shrank 13.6 percent in September as rising oil prices increased value of imports and as shipments to overseas markets fell; surplus fell to 1.5 trillion yen ($14.2 billion) from 1.73 trillion yen in August; exports declined 1.4 percent, and imports rose 2.4 percent; trade surplus fell 12.4 percent, to 1.12 trillion yen (S)d
snippet: Japan's current-account surplus shrank 13.6 percent in September as rising oil prices increased value of imports and as shipments to overseas markets fell; surplus fell to 1.5 trillion yen ($14.2 billion) from 1.73 trillion yen in August; exports ...
lead_paragraph: Japan's current-account surplus shrank 13.6 percent in September as rising oil prices increased the value of imports and as shipments to overseas markets fell. The surplus, the broadest measure of a country's global trade, fell to 1.5 trillion yen ($14.2 billion) from 1.73 trillion yen in August, seasonally adjusted, the Ministry of Finance said. Exports fell 1.4 percent, and imports rose 2.4 percent. The trade surplus, which excludes trade in services, fell 12.4 percent, to 1.12 trillion yen.

lead_paragraph: Dimon, a tobacco-leaf dealer, agreed to buy a smaller competitor, the Standard Commercial Corporation, for about $255 million in stock, the companies said yesterday. The transaction values Standard Commercial's 13.7 million outstanding shares at $18.66 each, a 13.8 percent premium over the closing price on Friday. Including Standard Commercial's debt, the transaction is valued at about $670 million. Dimon shareholders will control 52 percent of the new company, which will be called DimonStandard. The company expects to save $40 million in annual costs and to increase earnings beginning next year. Investors will receive three Dimon shares for each share of Standard Commercial. Dimon is based in Danville, Va., and Standard Commercial is based in Wilson, N.C.

snippet: Author Ana Teresa Torres Op-Ed article, assessing presidential election, laments insignificance of Latin America as election issue; says Venezuelans were split in their support, but will continue to sell oil to America (M)
lead_paragraph: Caracas, Venezuela - The American election came only two days after a round of elections here in Venezuela, where we've endured more than five years of constant political conflict. Still, the re-election of President Bush has been the biggest news of the week here. Too bad the American candidates don't return the favor. I listened to the final debate between Mr. Bush and John Kerry, and was sorry that neither seemed to consider Latin America very important.

lead_paragraph: Exports from the Philippines rose 8.4 percent in September, compared with the month a year ago, to a record $3.6 billion, according to official statistics. But the pace of growth slowed as demand cooled for electronics, which make up two-thirds of the country's exports. Economists said Philippine exports were likely to slow further in the last quarter of the year as high oil prices damp global economic growth. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

abstract: Like a Japanese compact car, the nation's economy is built to go a long way on a little gas. And so, Japan should be one of the best-prepared countries in the world to deal with rising oil prices. But as oil prices linger around $50 a barrel, economists now say Japan may be among the hardest hit.     The Japanese economy depends less on oil than almost any nation, requiring only about half as much oil to generate $1 worth of economic growth as the United States. But while the surge in oil prices has had relatively little impact so far on corporate profits or consumer spending, the increase is beginning to take a toll on the economy by contributing to a decline in Japanese exports, the main engine of the recovery that began last year.
snippet: Like a Japanese compact car, the nation's economy is built to go a long way on a little gas. And so, Japan should be one of the best-prepared countries in the world to deal with rising oil prices. But as oil prices linger around $50 a barrel, econ...

But as oil prices linger around $50 a barrel, economists now say Japan may be among the hardest hit.

abstract: Russian Tax Ministry claims added $10 billion in back taxes from oil company Yukos, bringing company's total back tax bill to $17.5 billion (S)
snippet: Russian Tax Ministry claims added $10 billion in back taxes from oil company Yukos, bringing company's total back tax bill to $17.5 billion (S)
lead_paragraph: The Russian Tax Ministry served the oil company Yukos with claims for an additional $10 billion in back taxes, which would bring the company's total tax bill to $17.5 billion. Tax officials with the ministry finished an audit for Yukos for 2002, and as a result demanded 193 billion rubles ($6.7 billion) for that year, the Interfax news agency reported. Earlier, Yuganskneftegaz, the main production unit of Yukos, received a $3.3 billion back-tax claim, $2.3 billion for unpaid taxes in 2001 and $1 billion for 2002. As part of the Russian government's campaign against the company, the country's largest oil producer, Yukos already faced total back-tax claims of about $7.5 billion for the years 2000 and 2001. The company has almost fully repaid the $3.4 billion for 2000. The founder of Yukos, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, is in jail facing trial on separate criminal charges, and his detention was extended on Monday to Feb. 14 from Nov. 14. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

abstract: In the latest jousting between China and Japan over Russia's energy riches, China is talking with the Exxon Mobil Corporation about buying gas from the Sakhalin Island field, which many Japanese assumed would power their nation for decades to come.    The gas talks come as China rues its loss of a Siberian oil pipeline that was once promised to run to Manchuria. Instead, Russian officials made clear this fall that the pipeline would go to a Russian port on the Sea of Japan. Russian leaders changed their minds after Japan's government offered billions of dollars to help finance the pipeline, which could be a $12 billion, 2,500-mile oil project running from Lake Baikal to Nakhodka.

abstract: When Kenyans go to the gas pump, they have several options -- regular, super, premium, diesel and, increasingly, a choice that has many local motorists scratching their heads, unleaded.    Lead-free gasoline may be the fuel of choice in most of the world but sub-Saharan Africa lags years behind when it comes to converting to cleaner-burning gasoline. On this continent, gas is sold at slick, modern stations and at roadside stands, where vendors use their mouths to help siphon fuel from plastic jugs. Many motorists mistakenly regard unleaded gas as suitable only for the latest model cars.

abstract: Bank of Thailand raises its benchmark interest rate to 1.75 percent from 1.5 percent in effort to offset inflationary effects of higher oil prices (S)1
snippet: Bank of Thailand raises its benchmark interest rate to 1.75 percent from 1.5 percent in effort to offset inflationary effects of higher oil prices (S)1
lead_paragraph: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, raised its benchmark interest rate to 1.75 percent from 1.5 percent in an effort to offset the inflationary effects of higher oil prices. It was the second time the bank had increased its 14-day repurchase rate in two months. Economists say Thailand's economy is one of the most vulnerable to higher fuel costs in Southeast Asia. The government has been subsidizing fuel prices to reduce the impact on voters before a general election next year, but it has been forced to allow some fuel prices to rise, contributing to slower economic growth and an inflation rate of 3.6 percent. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

abstract: Section of Route 9 near Sayreville, NJ, is expected to reopen to normal traffic after closure because of large fuel spill when fuel tanker overturned and burst into flames (S)
snippet: Section of Route 9 near Sayreville, NJ, is expected to reopen to normal traffic after closure because of large fuel spill when fuel tanker overturned and burst into flames (S)
lead_paragraph: A section of Route 9 near Sayreville was expected to reopen to normal traffic by early this morning after it was closed yesterday because of a large fuel spill, the police said. Thousands of gallons of gasoline gushed onto the highway after a fuel tanker overturn and burst into flames in Sayreville at about 2:20 a.m., the authorities said. Damage to the highway and a police investigation led to massive traffic jams during the morning rush hour, but all lanes of Route 9 were expected to be open for normal traffic by the morning rush today, according to the Sayreville Police Department. Officials at New Jersey Transit, whose commuter bus service was disrupted, said it expected to have normal bus service this morning. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

abstract: Germany's leading research institutes say economic growth is likely to slow in 2005 as result of higher oil prices and slow exports; project growth rate in gross domestic product of 1.5 percent next year; expect budget deficit of 3.5 percent, which would violate 3 percent limit set for countries using euro currency (S)
snippet: Germany's leading research institutes say economic growth is likely to slow in 2005 as result of higher oil prices and slow exports; project growth rate in gross domestic product of 1.5 percent next year; expect budget deficit of 3.5 percent, whic...
lead_paragraph: Economic growth is likely to slow next year as a result of high oil prices and slow exports, the country's leading research institutes said in a joint forecast. The twice-yearly report, which is used by the government in preparing its economic forecasts, projected a growth rate in the gross domestic product of 1.5 percent next year. The institutes revised their forecast for the current year to 1.8 percent from 1.5 percent. The report said the projected rate would lead to a German budget deficit of 3.5 percent, which would violate the 3 percent limit set for countries using the euro currency. Petra Kappl (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petróleo Brasileiro, said that it would raise gasoline and diesel prices to deal with the recent surge in energy prices but that the increase was less than expected. Analysts said that the move was intended to prevent a higher rate of inflation. Petrobras, as the company is widely known, said that refinery prices for gasoline and diesel would increase by 2.4 percent and 4.8 percent, respectively. Analysts expected an increase of as much as 10 percent and said Petrobras might have to raise prices again. Todd Benson (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The Russian government will sell a majority stake of the Yuganskneftegas unit of Yukos at an auction, with a lower-than-expected starting price of slightly more than $4 billion, according to the Interfax news agency. The government said that it would sell 76.8 percent of Yuganskneftegas, which produces 60 percent of the oil for Yukos, the No. 1 producer, as payment for the company's $7.5 billion in back taxes and penalties, Interfax reported. Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, the investment bank hired by the Russian government to assess the value of Yuganskneftegas, said that the entire unit could be worth $14.7 billion to $17.3 billion. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Thai Oil, Thailand's largest oil refiner, raised about $790 million selling a 45 percent stake to the public this week, in the country's largest initial public offering. Both foreign and local investors, eager to profit from record oil prices and refining margins, submitted orders for many times the number of shares on sale. Most of the shares belonged to creditors who took them in lieu of roughly $900 million in debt when the company defaulted on $2 billion in debt after the Asian financial crisis of 1997 and 1998. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

abstract: Editorial notes that scandal over alleged corruption in Iraq's oil-for-food program is under multiple investigations in United States, in Iraq and at United Nations; holds that nothing has surfaced so far to suggest that sanctions were failing in their main purpose, or that Bush administration's precipitous invasion was necessary or that UN is fatally hobbled by corruption or incompetence
snippet: Editorial notes that scandal over alleged corruption in Iraq's oil-for-food program is under multiple investigations in United States, in Iraq and at United Nations; holds that nothing has surfaced so far to suggest that sanctions were failing in ...
lead_paragraph: So much flak has been thrown at United Nations programs to constrain Saddam Hussein's oil revenues and weapons purchases by those charging corruption that the average citizen must be reeling in confusion. The report issued last week by Charles Duelfer, the chief United States weapons inspector, indicates that Iraq generated $11 billion in illicit revenue, imported forbidden military equipment and bribed companies, individuals and government officials around the world to support its efforts to end sanctions. The emerging scandal is already under multiple investigations in this country, in Iraq and at the United Nations. But nothing that has surfaced so far suggests that the sanctions were failing in their main purpose, that the Bush administration's precipitous invasion was necessary or that the United Nations is fatally hobbled by corruption or incompetence.

headline.main: That Cloud Over the United Nations

abstract: Boyd Group chairman Michael Boyd says soaring oil prices are likely to be boon for aircraft manufacturers who are producing new fuel-efficient planes, address to group's annual industry outlook conference, Denver; traffic on regional airlines was up 28.1 percent in second quarter of 2004; average passenger trip-length for regional airlines in quarter was 417 miles, up 10.4 percent over period last year; online hotel check-in has arrived; customers at Radisson Hotels and Resorts in US can check in to their rooms on Internet as early as seven days before arrival; Boeing says it has five new commitments for orders for its top-of-the-line Boeing Business Jets; American Airlines cuts its business fares from select US cities to dozens of destinations in Caribbean, Mexico and Latin America; photo (Memo Pad column) (M)
snippet: Boyd Group chairman Michael Boyd says soaring oil prices are likely to be boon for aircraft manufacturers who are producing new fuel-efficient planes, address to group's annual industry outlook conference, Denver; traffic on regional airlines was ...
lead_paragraph: THE KEY TO SURVIVAL -- Soaring oil prices, a bane for the already staggering airline industry, are likely to be a boon for aircraft manufacturers who are producing new fuel-efficient planes. That is the opinion of Michael Boyd, chairman of the Boyd Group, an aviation forecasting company whose annual two-day industry outlook conference opened in Denver yesterday. Having pared costs nearly as much as possible, "the big job airlines have to do to survive is to reduce fuel consumption," Mr. Boyd said. "New fuel-efficient airliners will be a survival necessity." Embraer's fuel-efficient line of regional jets with 80 to 150 seats stands to gain popularity at the expense of smaller regional jets with 50 or fewer seats, he said. Boeing's existing 737-600 line and the 7E7 long-range jet it is developing should also fare well, he said. In its annual fleet forecast, the Boyd Group projected that 1,000 7E7's could eventually be sold, while demand for wide-body aircraft will continue to wane. At the same conference, Ray Neidl, an airline analyst with Calyon Securities, predicted that oil prices were accelerating the timetable for major changes in the industry. Most of the network airlines "are trading close to bankruptcy levels, so the markets are trying to tell us something," he said. If oil prices remain high and airlines cannot raise fares because of fierce competition, mergers and liquidations could whittle the number of network airlines to just three within two years, from six today, he said.

headline.main: The Key to Survival

abstract: Millhouse Capital regains controlling stake in Russian oil company Sibneft in first step of cancellation of Sibneft's merger agreement with Yukos, another russian oil company (S)
snippet: Millhouse Capital regains controlling stake in Russian oil company Sibneft in first step of cancellation of Sibneft's merger agreement with Yukos, another russian oil company (S)
lead_paragraph: Millhouse Capital said it had regained a controlling stake in the Russian oil company Sibneft in the first step of the cancellation of Sibneft's merger agreement with another Russian oil company, Yukos. Millhouse, a holding company controlled by the Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, held a controlling stake in Sibneft before the two oil companies agreed to merge a year ago. Sibneft called off the deal after Yukos's founder and former chief executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, was arrested and jailed on charges of fraud and tax evasion. Yukos still holds a 35 percent stake in Sibneft. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank left interest rates unchanged at 2 percent as rising oil prices cast a shadow over Europe's economic recovery. The bank's board, meeting in Brussels, decided to leave rates at their current historically low level for the 16th consecutive month. Jean-Claude Trichet, left, the bank's president, said Europe's recovery remained on track, though he warned that oil prices, trading at record levels of about $52 a barrel, could hamper growth. lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi visited Libya as his government continued to come under fire for flying hundreds of African migrants who had reached Italian shores immediately back to Africa, specifically Tripoli. Mr. Berlusconi and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi were to open a 335-mile gas pipeline between their countries, but they were also expected to hold further talks on curbing the increasing numbers of illegal immigrants coming to Italy from Libya. More than 1,500 people landed by boat on the tiny southern island of Lampedusa over the last week. Rights groups have criticized Italy's new policy of instant deportation to Africa, saying legitimate asylum seekers may be prevented from pleading their cases. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

abstract: Yukos confirms Russia seeks 27.8 billion rubles ($950 million) in back taxes and penalties from its largest unit, Yuganskneftegas, for 2002; already owes $7.5 billion in back taxes for 2000 and 2001; Natural Resources Ministry will weigh status of unit's operating licenses (S)
snippet: Yukos confirms Russia seeks 27.8 billion rubles ($950 million) in back taxes and penalties from its largest unit, Yuganskneftegas, for 2002; already owes $7.5 billion in back taxes for 2000 and 2001; Natural Resources Ministry will weigh status of...
lead_paragraph: Russian tax authorities sent a bill for back taxes and penalties worth 27.8 billion rubles ($950 million) to Yukos's largest subsidiary, Yuganskneftegas, for the year 2002, the parent company confirmed. Yukos, Russia's largest oil producer, already owes $7.5 billion in back taxes for 2000 and 2001. The company has paid off about $2.5 billion of that total. Also, the Ministry of Natural Resources will meet tomorrow to consider the status of Yuganskneftegas's operating licenses, the Interfax news agency reported. If its licenses are revoked, that would cut the value of Yuganskneftegas, which produces about 60 percent of Yukos's oil and is currently being appraised for sale by investment bankers. A valuation report to the government is expected soon. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

abstract: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column says Pres Bush refuses to impose gasoline tax, which would be best way to fight global war on terrorism; holds that tax would dampen demand for oil from Saudi Arabia and other Mideast countries, which until now have resisted modernization and reform by buying off their citizens with oil money; notes that any innovation in Arab world can be seen only in places with little or no oil (M)
snippet: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column says Pres Bush refuses to impose gasoline tax, which would be best way to fight global war on terrorism; holds that tax would dampen demand for oil from Saudi Arabia and other Mideast countries, which until now have ...
lead_paragraph: Of all the shortsighted policies of President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney, none have been worse than their opposition to energy conservation and a gasoline tax. If we had imposed a new gasoline tax after 9/11, demand would have been dampened and gas today would probably still be $2 a gallon. But instead of the extra dollar going to Saudi Arabia -- where it ends up with mullahs who build madrasas that preach intolerance -- that dollar would have gone to our own Treasury to pay down our own deficit and finance our own schools. In fact, the Bush energy policy should be called No Mullah Left Behind.

abstract: Crude oil prices reach $50 a barrel; Sen John Kerry accuses Pres Bush of breaking vow that oil from Iraq would lower oil prices to $28 barrel (S)
snippet: Crude oil prices reach $50 a barrel; Sen John Kerry accuses Pres Bush of breaking vow that oil from Iraq would lower oil prices to $28 barrel (S)
lead_paragraph: After crude oil prices reached $50 a barrel on Tuesday and held at that price yesterday, Senator John Kerry accused President Bush of breaking a vow that oil from Iraq would lower oil prices to $28 a barrel. "The president promised us the oil would pay for the war, but we know that those oil pipes are being blown up," Mr. Kerry, the Democratic presidential nominee, said in Madison, Wis. "We know that $50 a barrel isn't as bad as it might get because analysts are now telling us that the price may go up to $60." He added, "The average American is going to feel this pain. Haliburton's not feeling the pain. The people in Saudi Arabia, the Middle East, who get the money aren't feeling the pain." In response to similar comments by Senator John Edwards, Scott McClellan, the White House press secretary, on Tuesday said the rising oil prices reflected a failure of Senate Democrats to approve the president's energy plan, and on the recent hurricanes, brushing off the notion of the Iraq war's influence. "What happens here is that we go through this year after year because we manage through patchwork crisis management instead of passing comprehensive solutions," Mr. McClellan said.

abstract: China agrees to pay in advance for shipments next month of crude oil from Russia's Yukos oil company (S)
snippet: China agrees to pay in advance for shipments next month of crude oil from Russia's Yukos oil company (S)
lead_paragraph: China agreed to pay in advance for shipments next month of crude oil from Yukos, Russia's largest oil exporter, easing concern about supply disruptions. Yukos said on Monday that it would reduce rail shipments to China as a result of a cash drain caused by the Russian government's demands for $7.5 billion in back taxes. Gennadi Fadeyev, the chief executive of Russian Railways, said China had proposed an advance payment for a shipment of 367,000 barrels of oil that would be part of Yukos's shipments to the country next month.

abstract: Editorial in series Campaign 2004: The Big Issues, focuses on Pres Bush's and Sen John Kerry's positions on various energy issues; says Bush's dominant strategy is to ramp up production rather than promote energy efficiency; says Kerry as presidential candidate has reduced ambitious but achievable goals he promoted during primaries, opting for softer pledge to 'update and strengthen' fuel standards
snippet: Editorial in series Campaign 2004: The Big Issues, focuses on Pres Bush's and Sen John Kerry's positions on various energy issues; says Bush's dominant strategy is to ramp up production rather than promote energy efficiency; says Kerry as presiden...
lead_paragraph: Presidential candidates have long dangled the promise of "energy independence" in front of the American voter. And all have known that it is an unattainable goal, largely because the United States, which uses one-quarter of the world's oil production, owns less than 3 percent of the world's oil reserves. What America can do, however, is reduce imports -- by producing cars that require less gasoline and by developing other fuels that cars can run on. Over time, such a strategy could enhance our energy security and give us more influence over prices. It would also make a big dent in America's emissions of global warming gases.

lead_paragraph: European airlines may have trouble meeting earnings forecasts because of high oil prices, Standard & Poor's said yesterday. Additionally, airlines and manufacturers of airplane parts "could suffer weakening credit quality," analyst Leigh Bailey wrote in a report. The only way for airlines to avoid this weakening is to pass fuel costs to consumers, the rating agency report said. That may prove difficult. Competition has increased in recent years, as new low-cost carriers entered the market, undercutting prices set by more established airlines. Heather Timmons (NYT)

lead_paragraph: This summer, Americans continued to rack up highway miles. Even while higher gas prices raised vacationing and commuting costs, most drivers acted as though this was a temporary glitch, complacently looking forward to the return of reasonable prices. For decades, Americans have grown too accustomed to cheap gas, buying S.U.V.'s and V-8's, driving more and more miles per capita every year. We are now more dependent on imported oil than ever before. But is there any viable alternative? Our own history offers us a possible solution.

lead_paragraph: IHS Energy, which provides maps and technical databases to oil and natural gas producers, bought Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting company founded by the author Daniel Yergin. Mr. Yergin will continue to oversee Cambridge Energy's research and will serve on IHS Energy's governing board. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. IHS Energy is owned by the Thyssen-Bornemisza Group, a closely held European conglomerate. Cambridge Energy, based in Cambridge, Mass., was majority-owned by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc., a buyout firm based in New York. Mr. Yergin is the author of "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power," a history of the oil industry that won the Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction in 1992.

lead_paragraph: Kinder Morgan Energy, a pipeline partnership, bought the Kaston Pipeline Company from the closely held Western Refining for about $100 million in cash. The 450-mile pipeline can carry as much as 115,000 barrels of oil daily from fields in West Texas, Kinder Morgan said, adding that the purchase will increase cash available for the partnership's holders by about $18 million a year. The system includes loading and storage facilities. The chief executive, Richard Kinder, said in a statement that the company would invest $11 million over the next five years to upgrade the system.

lead_paragraph: AIRLINE FOOD -- Two years after free meals became largely a memory (good or bad) in the coach cabins of many domestic flights, American Airlines is considering joining competitors that started selling meals to passengers after eliminating free meals during the post-9/11 slump in business. American said it would begin testing in-flight food sales in September on selected flights, including some between Dallas and New York and New York and Phoenix. Meals will cost $5 to $7. If the tests are successful and American expands the service throughout its domestic schedule, the airline, the world's largest, will join most major airlines and a handful of low-cost carriers in selling food in coach on some or all flights. (In business and first class, free meals are still the norm.) Among the major carriers, only Continental still serves free meals in coach on most domestic flights.

abstract: Indonesia's state-owned oil and gas company Pertamina decides not to extend contract with Exxon Mobil to develop one of country's largest oil fields when contract expires in 2010; Exxon Mobil bought contract, to manage Cepu fields in central Java, on Pertamina's behalf in 1999 only to discover in 2001 that it held much more oil than previously believed; Pertamina then said that if it did not get more of revenue, it would not renew contract (S)
snippet: Indonesia's state-owned oil and gas company Pertamina decides not to extend contract with Exxon Mobil to develop one of country's largest oil fields when contract expires in 2010; Exxon Mobil bought contract, to manage Cepu fields in central Java,...
lead_paragraph: Indonesia's state-owned oil and gas company, Pertamina, has decided not to extend a contract with Exxon Mobil to develop one of the country's largest oil fields when the contract expires in 2010. Exxon Mobil bought the contract, to manage the Cepu field in central Java, on Pertamina's behalf in 1999 only to discover in 2001 that it held much more oil than previously believed. Pertamina then said that if it did not get more of the revenue, it would not renew the contract. The companies have been at loggerheads since over how to divide the proceeds. A Pertamina official told a parliamentary commission this week that Pertamina would develop Cepu alone. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

abstract: Kerr-McGee Corp raises its forecast for oil output in third quarter because field in Gulf of Mexico is exceeding expectations; expects oil production to average 156,000 to 170,000 per day, beating earlier forecast of 142,000 to 155,000 (S)
snippet: Kerr-McGee Corp raises its forecast for oil output in third quarter because field in Gulf of Mexico is exceeding expectations; expects oil production to average 156,000 to 170,000 per day, beating earlier forecast of 142,000 to 155,000 (S)
lead_paragraph: The Kerr-McGee Corporation has raised its forecast for oil output in the third quarter because a field in the Gulf of Mexico is exceeding expectations. The company expects oil production to average 156,000 to 170,000 barrels a day, beating an earlier forecast of 142,000 to 155,000, a spokeswoman, Debbie Schramm, said. Higher oil production at the Gulf of Mexico field, called Nansen, will delay gas output there, Kerr-McGee said. The company, based in Oklahoma City, pared its third-quarter projection for daily gas production to a range of 1.06 billion to 1.14 billion cubic feet a day from a previous forecast of 1.16 billion to 1.24 billion.

abstract: Bank of Thailand raises its 14-day repurchase rate to 1.5 percent from 1.25 percent to curb inflationary impact of higher oil prices (S)
snippet: Bank of Thailand raises its 14-day repurchase rate to 1.5 percent from 1.25 percent to curb inflationary impact of higher oil prices (S)
lead_paragraph: Thailand's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate for the first time in more than a year yesterday to curb the inflationary impact of higher oil prices. The Bank of Thailand raised its 14-day repurchase rate to 1.5 percent from 1.25 percent. In recent weeks, the bank has warned of a possible credit bubble that could leave the economy vulnerable to rising fuel costs and higher interest rates. The government has so far used oil subsidies to cushion the impact of higher prices, but it has begun rolling out energy-saving measures as the cost of its subsidies rises. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

abstract: Anadarko Petroleum Corp agrees to sell some Canadian properties to Advantage Energy Income Fund for $142 million under plan to rid assets and cut debt; 35 oil and gas fields included in sale have proven reserves equivalent to 9.9 million barrels of oil (S)
snippet: Anadarko Petroleum Corp agrees to sell some Canadian properties to Advantage Energy Income Fund for $142 million under plan to rid assets and cut debt; 35 oil and gas fields included in sale have proven reserves equivalent to 9.9 million barrels o...
lead_paragraph: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, a producer of oil and natural gas, agreed to sell some Canadian properties to the Advantage Energy Income Fund for $142 million under a plan to shed assets and cut debt. The 35 oil and gas fields included in the sale have proven reserves equivalent to 9.9 million barrels of oil, net of royalties, Anadarko said in a statement. Anadarko, based near Houston, said net production from the fields was equivalent to 4,500 barrels of oil a day. Advantage, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, said the transaction, expected to close by Sept. 30, would help increase its monthly payments to investors by 8.7 percent, to 25 Canadian cents (19 cents) a unit.

abstract: Southwest Airlines will cut 88 daily flights from its fall schedule to concentrate more of its planes on highly competitive markets like Philadelphia; United Airlines reduces to 15,000 from 25,000 number of Mileage Plus miles needed to claim free coach seat--but only on nonstop round-trip flights of 750 miles or less each way; Qantas Airways, Lufthansa and British Airways are increasing their fuel surcharges; rise in air travel means fewer planes are being mothballed in desert storage areas in California and Arizona; 2,390 commercial aircraft were in storage in July, compared with 2,674 year ago; Independence Air is running fare sale that includes $29 on-way price for nonstop flights to and from Pittsburgh; study at Cornell University's School of Hotel Administration questions whether hotel chains are getting their money's worth to maintain guest-loyalty programs; finds there is only 'weak connection' between guest satisfaction and loyalty; photo (Memo Pad column) (M)
snippet: Southwest Airlines will cut 88 daily flights from its fall schedule to concentrate more of its planes on highly competitive markets like Philadelphia; United Airlines reduces to 15,000 from 25,000 number of Mileage Plus miles needed to claim free ...
lead_paragraph: SOUTHWEST SHIFTS ITS SCHEDULES -- Southwest Airlines said it would cut 88 daily flights from its fall schedule to concentrate more of its planes on highly competitive markets like Philadelphia, the US Airways bastion where Southwest began service May 9. The schedule changes will trim flight frequencies in small and medium-size cities like Albuquerque; Kansas City, Mo.; New Orleans; Little Rock, Ark.; and Austin, El Paso and Lubbock, Tex. But big hub airports like Los Angeles International, Houston Intercontinental and Dallas-Fort Worth International will also lose a small number of daily flights, said Ed Stewart, a Southwest spokesman. ''Philadelphia is certainly one of the places where we are growing faster than any of our other city openings in recent history,'' he said. Other city-pair routes on which Southwest will add flights include: Hobby Airport at Houston and Orlando, Fla.; Houston Hobby and Los Angeles; Baltimore and Nashville; Chicago Midway and Tampa, Fla.; Las Vegas and Tucson, Ariz.; and St. Louis and Oklahoma City. Joe Brancatelli, the publisher of the business-travel Web site JoeSentMe.com, said Southwest's move made sense. ''It's what smart airlines do,'' he said. ''Only in the airline industry is inventory management considered a radical proposition.''

abstract: India cuts taxes on petroleum products to curb effect of high energy prices on growth and on inflation (S)
snippet: India cuts taxes on petroleum products to curb effect of high energy prices on growth and on inflation (S)
lead_paragraph: India cut taxes on petroleum products to curb the effect of high energy prices on growth and on inflation, the finance ministry said. The customs duty on gasoline and diesel fuel was cut to 15 percent from 20 percent and the excise tax on the products was cut to 23 percent from 26 percent, the ministry said. India's wholesale price index rose to 7.6 percent in July, a three-and-a-half-year high. Oil is the country's biggest import. Saritha Rai (NYT)

abstract: Philippines posts trade deficit of $142 million in June, reversing last year's surplus, as value of imports of oil and other petroleum products more than doubles (S)
snippet: Philippines posts trade deficit of $142 million in June, reversing last year's surplus, as value of imports of oil and other petroleum products more than doubles (S)
lead_paragraph: The Philippines posted a trade deficit of $142 million in June, the government said, reversing last year's surplus as higher oil prices sent the value of imports up 18 percent, to $3.455 billion. Imports of fuel and other petroleum products more than doubled, to $517.5 million, while imports of electronic components, considered a leading indicator of Philippine exports, rose at a much slower pace of 6.7 percent. This month, the government announced that exports in June rose 8.2 percent, to $3.3 million. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

abstract: New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection will begin regular inspections of more than 22,000 underground storage tanks at service stations throughout state as part of program to prevent pollution (S)
snippet: New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection will begin regular inspections of more than 22,000 underground storage tanks at service stations throughout state as part of program to prevent pollution (S)
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection announced yesterday that it would begin regular inspections of more than 22,000 underground storage tanks at service stations throughout the state as part of a program to prevent pollution. The department is hiring 18 inspectors to examine those tanks and more than 8,000 locations where heating oil, gasoline and waste oil are handled, as part of a program approved last November in a referendum that set aside $2 million annually. The inspections do not apply to storage tanks under 2,200 gallons, said Fred Mumford, a spokesman for the department. Each of the 8,000 locations must register with it and be inspected every three years. John Holl (NYT)

abstract: ChevronTexaco was ordered to pay $41 million to more than 80 residents of Sunburst, Mont, whose properties were damaged by 1955 underground pipeline leak (S)
snippet: ChevronTexaco was ordered to pay $41 million to more than 80 residents of Sunburst, Mont, whose properties were damaged by 1955 underground pipeline leak (S)
lead_paragraph: ChevronTexaco was ordered to pay $41 million to more than 80 residents of Sunburst, Mont., whose properties were damaged by a 1955 underground pipeline leak. A state court jury in Cascade County, Mont., awarded $16.1 million in compensatory damages and $25 million in punitive damages, said Keith Marr, a lawyer in Great Falls, Mont. ''There is no health risk to the people of the town of Sunburst associated with the contamination under the refinery,'' a ChevronTexaco spokesman, Michael Barrett, said in a statement. ''We sympathize with those residents who have been concerned about the loss of any value in their property.'' Mr. Barrett said the company would appeal.

abstract: Investor confidence in Germany fell for first month in three in August amid concern about record oil prices and slowing growth in US and Japan; index of institutional and analyst sentiment compiled by ZEW Center for European Economic Research fell to 45.3, from 48.4 in July; graph (S)
snippet: Investor confidence in Germany fell for first month in three in August amid concern about record oil prices and slowing growth in US and Japan; index of institutional and analyst sentiment compiled by ZEW Center for European Economic Research fell...
lead_paragraph: Investor confidence in Germany fell for the first month in three in August amid concern about record oil prices and slowing growth in the United States and Japan. The index of institutional and analyst sentiment compiled by the ZEW Center for European Economic Research fell to 45.3, from 48.4 in July. The drop in confidence adds to evidence that German economic growth may slow this quarter. ''The recent economic data from the U.S. gives reason to be concerned that the very strong export demand in Germany up to this point could weaken,'' the center said. ''In addition, the high oil price reduces the purchasing power of consumers and puts pressure on domestic demand.''

lead_paragraph: The Calpine Corporation, owner of power plants in 20 states, agreed to sell its Canadian natural-gas reserves and petroleum assets to the PrimeWest Energy Trust for 825 million Canadian dollars ($631 million) to raise cash to pay debts. The sale includes the equivalent of about 221 billion cubic feet of proven gas reserves that produce about 61 million cubic feet a day, Calpine said. It also included Calpine Natural Gas Trust's 25 percent interest in the equivalent of about 80 billion cubic feet of proven reserves. Calpine is selling assets to reduce debt that has almost quadrupled since 2000 to about $18.1 billion.

lead_paragraph: National-Oilwell, a maker of oil and gas drilling equipment, agreed to buy Varco International for about $2.4 billion in stock, extending a four-year expansion. Shareholders of Varco will receive 0.8363 share of National-Oilwell for each of their shares, the companies said. The transaction values Varco at $24.30 a share, above its closing price Wednesday of $23.62 a share. National-Oilwell has acquired 21 companies since 2000. The combination would create the nation's largest equipment maker for oil field services companies, surpassing FMC Technologies. Both companies are based in Houston.

abstract: Marathon Oil Corp and Amerada Hess Corp says Securities and Exchange Commission is probing their payments to government of Equatorial Guinea; Marathon, which produces natural gas off coast of Equatorial Guinea and owns part of methanol plant there, has paid or agreed to pay Equatorial Guinea Pres Teodoro Obiang more than $2 million to buy land to expand operations; Hess allegedly paid Equatorial Guinea officials almost $1 million for building leases (S)
snippet: Marathon Oil Corp and Amerada Hess Corp says Securities and Exchange Commission is probing their payments to government of Equatorial Guinea; Marathon, which produces natural gas off coast of Equatorial Guinea and owns part of methanol plant there...
lead_paragraph: The Marathon Oil Corporation and the Amerada Hess Corporation said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating their payments to the government of Equatorial Guinea. The companies are cooperating with the S.E.C., spokesmen for Marathon and Hess said separately. The inquiry follows a Senate subcommittee's report issued last month on financial dealings between the Riggs National Corporation and foreign governments. Marathon, which produces natural gas off the coast of Equatorial Guinea and owns part of a methanol plant there, has paid or agreed to pay the West African country's president, Teodoro Obiang, more than $2 million to buy land to expand operations, the Senate report said. It said Hess paid officials of Equatorial Guinea almost $1 million for building leases. Of 28 leases Hess identified, 18 were with people ''connected to the government or the Obiang family,'' the report said.

abstract: More than 25,000 gallons of fuel oil spill into Neches River, Texas, when towboat accidentally pushes barge against tanker, piercing hull (S)
snippet: More than 25,000 gallons of fuel oil spill into Neches River, Texas, when towboat accidentally pushes barge against tanker, piercing hull (S)
lead_paragraph: More than 25,000 gallons of fuel oil escaped into the Neches River in southeast Texas when a towboat accidentally pushed a barge against a Danish tanker, piercing its hull, at an anchorage between Port Arthur and Beaumont, said Jim Suydam, a spokesman for the state General Land Office. Two miles of the river were cordoned with booms to help contain the spill from the tanker, but some of the fuel reached the shoreline, said Chuck King, a vice president of Buffalo Marine Service of Houston, which owns the barge. Environmental teams were dispatched to aid in the cleanup. Steve Barnes (NYT)

lead_paragraph: AIRLINES RETREAT ON FARE INCREASES -- Analysts say the domestic airline business cannot make money with oil priced at more than $40 a barrel, but the travel market keeps telling major airlines that passengers are not willing to chip in for gas no matter how high oil goes. Another attempt by airlines to impose small fare increases to offset high fuel costs collapsed yesterday after AMR's American Airlines retreated from a $10 price increase on round-trip fares that it announced on Thursday. Competitors also dropped their fare increases. Over the weekend, even several low-cost carriers such as ATA and Midwest had tried to impose the fare increases, indicating just how desperate the industry has become over fuel costs at a time when fierce competition is keeping domestic fares low.

lead_paragraph: EXECUTIVES can be marvelously creative when they have to disclose disappointing results to investors. A prime excuse for bad news, especially among retailers, is weather -- handy because it works rain or shine. If it was too sunny during the quarter, everyone was at the beach and nobody shopped. abstract: the triumph of theÔ
snippet: the triumph of theÔ
lead_paragraph: Pity, if you can, the richest man in Russia. With a fortune estimated at $15 billion, Mikhail Khodorkovsky is on trial for fraud, embezzlement and tax evasion and faces a 10-year jail term. His oil company, Yukos, has been hit with a tax bill of $3.4 billion, and the government is threatening to seize its most valuable assets. Although many nations, including America, tend to err on the side of courtesy to wealthy defendants, Russia does not: denied bail since his arrest in October, Khodorkovsky has not been allowed to prepare for trial from the comfort of one of his mansions, and when he is brought to court, he is placed in a metal cage.

Under competitive pressure from discount carriers, most major airlines have managed to cut core costs significantly. Airlines are still projected to report total losses of $550 million for the second quarter.

abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group, under pressure by Nigerian labor unions for months to name Nigerians to senior posts, names Basil Omiyi to head Shell Petroleum Development Co of Nigeria; he is first Nigerian appointed to lead major oil multinational unit in Nigeria; photo (S)
snippet: Royal Dutch/Shell Group, under pressure by Nigerian labor unions for months to name Nigerians to senior posts, names Basil Omiyi to head Shell Petroleum Development Co of Nigeria; he is first Nigerian appointed to lead major oil multinational unit...
lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group named a Nigerian to head the company's biggest African subsidiary. The appointment of Basil Omiyi followed months of pressure by Nigerian labor unions which threatened production shutdowns to get Nigerians in senior positions with the company. Mr. Omiyi, 58, left, will become managing director of the Shell Petroleum Development Company of Nigeria on Sept. 1, the company said. Mr. Omiyi is the first Nigerian ever appointed to lead a major oil multinational subsidiary in Nigeria. He joined the multinational in 1970 as a petroleum engineer and currently is production director of Shell's Nigerian subsidiary.

abstract: ChevronTexaco Corp says its executives have gone to Tripoli in recent months for preliminary talks with Libyan oil executives on possibility of investing in Libya's oil and gas industry (S)
snippet: ChevronTexaco Corp says its executives have gone to Tripoli in recent months for preliminary talks with Libyan oil executives on possibility of investing in Libya's oil and gas industry (S)
lead_paragraph: Executives of the ChevronTexaco Corporation have met with Libyan oil executives in Tripoli in recent months to discuss the possibility of investing in the former pariah state's oil and gas industry, a company spokesman said yesterday. Characterizing the discussions as ''preliminary,'' a ChevronTexaco spokesman, Andy Norman, said the company was ''very interested'' in possibly returning to Libya now that the United States has lifted sanctions. Chevron was active in Libya for several decades before its joint venture operations with Texaco were taken over by a unit of Libya's National Oil Corporation in the late 1970's.

abstract: Plains Resources says Paul G Allen's Vulcan Capital has raised its takeover offer by 3 percent, to $423 million (S)
snippet: Plains Resources says Paul G Allen's Vulcan Capital has raised its takeover offer by 3 percent, to $423 million (S)
lead_paragraph: Plains Resources, which controls 14,000 miles of crude-oil pipeline, said that Paul G. Allen's Vulcan Capital had raised its takeover offer by 3 percent, to $423 million. The bid was increased to $17.25 a share, from $16.75, and is the final offer from Vulcan, Plains Resources said. A shareholder vote is set for July 22. Investors owning about 17 percent of the company's stock have already pledged their shares to Vulcan, Plains Resources said. Those investors include the chairman, James C. Flores, and the chief executive, John T. Raymond, who are joining with Mr. Allen to buy the company. Plains Resources, based in Houston, also said that it rejected a proposal last week from the Leucadia National to increase shareholder value as an alternative to the Vulcan bid. Under the plan, Plains Resources would borrow $175 million and use the cash to repurchase about 10 million shares.

lead_paragraph: PetroEcuador, the state oil company, said its oil production would probably rise 2.4 percent by year-end as it drills new wells and overhauls existing ones. Output will increase to 205,000 barrels a day, from 200,154 barrels currently, the Quito-based company said. The company said in April that it would spend $28 million to drill new wells and perform maintenance on others. PetroEcuador produces about 40 percent of the country's daily output of 500,000 barrels a day.

lead_paragraph: Petrobras, the Brazilian oil giant, has signed a $34 million deal to drill in the Iranian part of the Caspian Sea, the second deal the company has made in the last year, a company executive said. Last year, Iran's government-owned National Iranian Oil Company granted Petrobras a license to explore a 3,200-square-mile area of the Persian Gulf. The Iranian oil minister, Bijan Namdar Zanganeh, above, said that recent discoveries had pushed Iran ahead of Iraq as the No.2 holder of proven crude oil reserves, behind Saudi Arabia. Borzou Daragahi (NYT)

abstract: Op-Ed article by Bruce Babbitt says Bush administration and oil industry are turning their attention to balance of Arctic region of Alaska, having been thwarted in efforts to open Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to drilling; says administration now proposes to lease rights for oil and gas development in Teshekpuk Lake in biological heart of western Arctic, lake that is nesting and breeding ground for birds and critically important for indigenous Inupiat communities on Arctic slope; notes that scientific teams dispatched during Clinton administration recommended that Teshekpuk be protected area; says Interior Sec Gale Norton is expected to make final decision after hearings in Anchorage and Washington (M)
snippet: Op-Ed article by Bruce Babbitt says Bush administration and oil industry are turning their attention to balance of Arctic region of Alaska, having been thwarted in efforts to open Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to drilling; says administration no...
lead_paragraph: Thwarted by the public in its efforts to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to drilling, the Bush administration and the oil companies are now quietly turning their attention to the balance of the Arctic region of Alaska, all the way west to the Chukchi Sea, within sight of Siberia. In advance of its efforts, the administration has jettisoned environmental safeguards and is now threatening the traditional-use rights of the Alaska Natives who have hunted caribou and waterfowl along the Arctic slope for thousands of years.

abstract: Fuel transporter Buckeye Partners acquires five petroleum-product pipelines and 25 terminals from unit of Shell Oil Co division of Royal Dutch/Shell; $530 million deal will give Buckeye shipments to Chicago, St Louis and other Midwest cities (S)
snippet: Fuel transporter Buckeye Partners acquires five petroleum-product pipelines and 25 terminals from unit of Shell Oil Co division of Royal Dutch/Shell; $530 million deal will give Buckeye shipments to Chicago, St Louis and other Midwest cities (S)
lead_paragraph: Buckeye Partners, a fuel transporter, agreed to buy five petroleum-product pipelines and 25 terminals from a unit of the Shell Oil Company division of Royal Dutch/Shell. The $530 million deal will give Buckeye shipments to Chicago, St. Louis and other Midwest cities. The purchase will increase per-unit payouts to owners by 15 cents a year, Buckeye said. The partnership, based in Emmaus, Pa., is acquiring more than 855 miles of pipelines, including four lines from a ConocoPhillips refinery near St. Louis. The sale is the second in a week by Shell, which is shedding onshore pipelines.

abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group plans to take $330 million charge in second quarter because some of its assets in North Sea did not yield oil as expected; charge does not affect Shell's proven reserves; Shell also says it will sell some pipelines in US and its retail, commercial and marine assets in Peru (S)
snippet: Royal Dutch/Shell Group plans to take $330 million charge in second quarter because some of its assets in North Sea did not yield oil as expected; charge does not affect Shell's proven reserves; Shell also says it will sell some pipelines in US an...
lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said it planned to take a $330 million charge in the second quarter because some of its assets in the North Sea did not yield oil as expected. The charge does not affect Shell's proven reserves, which have been under scrutiny since the company said in January that it would reduce their value by 20 percent. Shell also said it would sell some pipelines in the United States and its retail, commercial and marine assets in Peru.

lead_paragraph: IN June, Barbara Moss noticed a new item on her monthly $260 lawn-care bill: a $6 gas surcharge. abstract: BP predicts higher second-quarter profit after raising production through TNK-BP, its joint venture in Russia with Tyumen Oil Co (S)
snippet: BP predicts higher second-quarter profit after raising production through TNK-BP, its joint venture in Russia with Tyumen Oil Co (S)
lead_paragraph: The oil giant BP said it expected profit to rise in the second quarter after increasing production through its joint venture in Russia. BP signed a $6.15 billion deal with the Tyumen Oil Company last summer, creating Russia's third-largest oil company. Overall production was up 17 percent in the second quarter, to 3.95 million barrels a day, BP said; the Russian deal, known as TNK-BP, added 890,000 barrels a day. Still, results will be held down by thinning margins in the refining businesses because of marketing costs, BP said. Heather Timmons (NYT)
