abstract: Airlines are filling more seats; Continental Airlines and Southwest Airlines say their load factor--percentage of available seats sold--and traffic increased in June from year ago; International Air Transport Association says all major regions of world are reporting air traffic levels above those of 2000, last normal year for industry; United Airlines raises most of its international fares 5 percent to cover increased fuel prices; Virgin Atlantic Airways is testing idea of staffing bars in its Upper Class Suites business-class cabins with bartenders who specialize in fancy cocktails; Hawaiian Airlines pilot Craig Kobyashi escorted passenger Joshua Gotbaum off plane last month before departure from Honolulu to San Francisco, saying he was not comfortable having him aboard; Gotbaum is court-appointed trustee overseeing carrier's bankruptcy reorganization; Kobyashi says many employees are emotional about Gotbaum for things he has done, such as freeze employees' pension plan (Memo Pad column) (M)
snippet: Airlines are filling more seats; Continental Airlines and Southwest Airlines say their load factor--percentage of available seats sold--and traffic increased in June from year ago; International Air Transport Association says all major regions of ...
lead_paragraph: AIRPLANES MORE CROWDED -- Feeling a little more cramped in coach these days? That's because the airlines are filling more seats. In June, for example, Continental Airlines' load factor -- the percentage of available seats sold -- was 82.4 percent, a record for June and an increase of 1.4 points over the month last year. Continental's traffic increased 12.2 percent over June 2003. Capacity, the overall number of seats available, rose 10.2 percent. The other major airline reporting June traffic so far is Southwest, which said its load factor was 78.8 percent, compared with 74.6 percent in June 2003. Southwest's traffic increased 11.9 percent, with a 5.9 percent rise in capacity.

abstract: Correction of Sept 20, Sept 25 and Oct 9 articles on Yukos, Russian oil company, which misstated ownership of Interfax news agency; agency is privately owned, not part of state-controlled media (S)
snippet: Correction of Sept 20, Sept 25 and Oct 9 articles on Yukos, Russian oil company, which misstated ownership of Interfax news agency; agency is privately owned, not part of state-controlled media (S)
lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day on Sept. 20 about an announcement by Yukos, the Russian oil company, that it would reduce some exports to China misstated the ownership of the Interfax news agency, which reported the development. (The error also occurred in articles on Sept. 25 and Oct. 9.) The agency is part of the Interfax Group, a privately held corporation established in 1989 as the former Soviet Union's first nongovernmental news organization; it is not part of a state-controlled enterprise. This correction was delayed for research into the ownership structure.

abstract: El Paso Corp, which this year slashed its assessment of oil and natural-gas reserves, plans to stem declining production and cut costs by increasing efficiency at its Gulf Coast drilling sites (S)
snippet: El Paso Corp, which this year slashed its assessment of oil and natural-gas reserves, plans to stem declining production and cut costs by increasing efficiency at its Gulf Coast drilling sites (S)
lead_paragraph: The El Paso Corporation, which this year slashed its assessment of oil and natural-gas reserves, said it planned to stem declining production and cut costs by increasing efficiency at its Gulf Coast drilling sites. Average daily production will rise to the equivalent of 825 million to 875 million cubic feet of natural gas this year and next, the company said. Output fell to the equivalent of 814 million cubic feet of gas a day in the current quarter through June 15. It was 956 million cubic feet in the first quarter. The company expects to spend $850 million this year and next on oil and gas production, executives said in a conference call with analysts and investors. More than 70 percent of this year's spending will be in the Gulf of Mexico, coastal sections of Louisiana and Texas, and in onshore fields in the Southern Plains and Rocky Mountain regions.

abstract: Magellan Midstream Partners will buy more than 2,000 miles of pipelines from unit of Shell Oil Co for $492.4 million, connecting company with Gulf Coast refineries and tapping new markets in Colorado and West Texas (S)
snippet: Magellan Midstream Partners will buy more than 2,000 miles of pipelines from unit of Shell Oil Co for $492.4 million, connecting company with Gulf Coast refineries and tapping new markets in Colorado and West Texas (S)
lead_paragraph: Magellan Midstream Partners agreed yesterday to buy more than 2,000 miles of pipelines from a unit of the Shell Oil Company for $492.4 million, connecting the company with Gulf Coast refineries and tapping new markets in Colorado and West Texas. The acquisition includes four pipeline systems as well as storage facilities that can hold about 6.4 million barrels of gasoline and other petroleum products, Magellan said. Magellan, based in Tulsa, Okla., operates a 6,700-mile pipeline system, the largest in the United States for refined petroleum products.

abstract: Gasoline with high-sulfur content emerges as leading environment concern around the world, greatly owing to tight oil market; demand is growing in radidly developing countries like China, India, Thailand, Mexico and Brazil, where ownership and use of cars and trucks is soaring; oil producers are pumping and selling all the oil they can to meet this demand, and extra oil they are able to bring to market is, to great extent, high in sulfur, or 'sour'; 'sweet' crude commands highest prices, so many refineries in China and elsewhere are buying cheaper sour crude and turning it into fuels that may contain many times more sulfur than gasoline or diesel sold in United States or Europe; environmentalists call sulfur world's biggest single contributor to air pollution; photos; graph (L)
snippet: Gasoline with high-sulfur content emerges as leading environment concern around the world, greatly owing to tight oil market; demand is growing in radidly developing countries like China, India, Thailand, Mexico and Brazil, where ownership and use...
lead_paragraph: With toxic lead finally disappearing from most of the world's gasoline, a new air pollution fight is emerging around the globe over how much sulfur to allow in fuel. Rapidly developing countries like China, India, Thailand, Mexico and Brazil, where ownership and use of cars and trucks is soaring, are on the front lines.

lead_paragraph: The formal occupation of Iraq came to an ignominious end yesterday with a furtive ceremony, held two days early to foil insurgent attacks, and a swift airborne exit for the chief administrator. In reality, the occupation will continue under another name, most likely until a hostile Iraqi populace demands that we leave. But it's already worth asking why things went so wrong.

lead_paragraph: An energy fund run by the Carlyle Group and Riverstone Holdings, in partnership with Capital C Energy L.L.C., agreed yesterday to buy a closely held oil and natural-gas producer, the Belden & Blake Corporation, for an undisclosed sum. Belden & Blake, owned by the buyout firm Texas Pacific Group, has proven reserves equivalent to about 360 billion cubic feet of gas in the Appalachians and Michigan, Carlyle and Riverstone said. Belden & Blake, based in Ohio, had 2003 sales of $109.1 million. The Carlyle Group, a private equity firm in Washington, and Riverstone, a New York investment company, announced in April that they had raised a $1.1 billion fund, Carlyle/Riverstone Global Energy & Power Fund II L.P., to buy energy assets.

But I want to step back and construct a better framework for myself to explain what's going on out there. Here's a few of the headlines I'd like to read while I'm gone.

snippet: El Paso Corp says providers of $3 billion of credit agree to wait until Aug 15 for financial reports delayed by restatement of oil and natural-gas reserves (S)
lead_paragraph: The El Paso Corporation, operator of the longest interstate natural-gas pipeline system in the nation, said yesterday that providers of $3 billion of credit had agreed to wait until Aug. 15 for financial reports delayed by a restatement of oil and natural-gas reserves. Waivers approved for a revolving credit line and other borrowing include a 29-day grace period should creditors declare default on debt exceeding a combined $100 million, El Paso said. The company, based in Houston, has not filed financial reports for the fourth quarter of 2003 or the first quarter of this year with the Securities and Exchange Commission, because of an audit that began after the company lowered its estimate of oil and natural-gas reserves by 41 percent in February.

lead_paragraph: The EnCana Corporation, an oil and natural gas producer, raised its output estimates for this year and 2005, citing strong natural gas production in the American Rockies and western Canada, as well as growth at its Alberta oil sands operation. lead_paragraph: Shares of the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, a United States oil and natural gas producer, rose yesterday after the company announced plans to sell more than $2.5 billion in assets and buy back up to $2 billion of its stock. The shares rose $1.50, or 2.7 percent, to $57.58 on the New York Stock Exchange. Anadarko, based near Houston, has been the top-performing oil and gas explorer in the last year among members of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The chief executive, James Hackett, said on Wednesday that Anadarko planned to sell properties that account for about 25 percent of output to strengthen its balance sheet and free resources for more promising projects.

snippet: Washington consulting firm PFC Energy says Royal Dutch/Shell's oil operations in Nigeria play role in feeding continuing conflict in country; Nigerian labor unions are in second day of nationwide strike to protest recent increase in gasoline price...
lead_paragraph: Royal Dutch/Shell's oil operations in Nigeria play a role in feeding the continuing conflict in the country, a company report has found. Nigerian labor unions were in the second day of a nationwide strike to protest the recent increase in gasoline prices there, the latest in a decade of demonstrations protesting how little of the profits reaped from the oil-rich country reach some of its citizens. The strike has halted transportation and closed stores and schools, but has not yet affected the amount of oil flowing from the region, energy experts said. Nigerian oil made up 11 percent of crude imports to the United States in the first quarter of 2004, according to PFC Energy, a Washington consulting firm. ''We sometimes feed conflict by the way we award contracts, gain access to land and deal with community representatives,'' said the Shell report, an annual review of the effect the company's policies have on sustainable development. Heather Timmons (NYT)

abstract: Union Pacific, biggest railroad in nation, says second-quarter earnings will fall fromyear ago on higher costs to end shipping delays and buy diesel fuel (S)
snippet: Union Pacific, biggest railroad in nation, says second-quarter earnings will fall fromyear ago on higher costs to end shipping delays and buy diesel fuel (S)
lead_paragraph: Union Pacific, the biggest railroad in the nation, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings would fall from a year ago on higher costs to end shipping delays and buy diesel fuel. The forecast was about a third lower than analysts' estimates. Earnings will be 60 to 65 cents a share, compared with $1.05 a share last year, the company said. The railroad said ''operational inefficiencies'' like a shortage of train crews and track congestion, coupled with a 30 percent rise in fuel costs, were increasing expenses. Shares of Union Pacific fell $1.21, or 2 percent, to $58.78.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, June 1 - Oil prices jumped to records on Tuesday, as traders in Europe and the United States reacted to the murder of 22 foreign workers in Khobar, Saudi Arabia, over the weekend. The Khobar attack and the surge in prices have cast a pall over a meeting of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries here this week, driving home a sense among the delegates that at in the short term at least, there is little they can do to bring prices down.

Industry experts gathered here for OPEC's meeting said that the decision sent a tepid message to oil markets about the group's commitment to lowering prices, which have been around $40 a barrel.

abstract: OPEC, at its recent meeting in Beirut, seemed to abdicate responsibility for record-high oil prices; 10 voting members of cartel did help drive up prices over last 18 months, but market OPEC has successfully managed over last five years seems to be slipping from its grip; OPEC can keep prices from falling by pumping less oil, but it has little power to curtail violence and political instability, and cannot keep prices from spiraling upward on bad news; that could mean continued high prices, which have hit $40 barrel over last month; drawing (M)
snippet: OPEC, at its recent meeting in Beirut, seemed to abdicate responsibility for record-high oil prices; 10 voting members of cartel did help drive up prices over last 18 months, but market OPEC has successfully managed over last five years seems to b...
lead_paragraph: AT their meeting here last week, members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries seemed to abdicate responsibility for the recent record-high oil prices. Purnomo Yusgiantoro, the group's president and Indonesia's minister of energy, complained in his opening remarks that ''the high prices have been caused by a combination of factors over which OPEC has no control -- speculation on futures markets, tightness in the U.S. gasoline market, geopolitical concerns and higher-than-expected oil demand growth, especially in China and the U.S.A.''

abstract: Russia's Yukos oil company says it may go bankrupt by end of 2004 if it is forced to pay billions of dollars in back taxes (S)
snippet: Russia's Yukos oil company says it may go bankrupt by end of 2004 if it is forced to pay billions of dollars in back taxes (S)
lead_paragraph: The oil producer Yukos warned that it might go bankrupt by the end of 2004 if forced to pay billions of dollars in back taxes. ''If the tax ministry actions continue, we can talk of the high likelihood of bankruptcy by the end of this year,'' Yukos said a day after a Moscow court upheld a lower court decision ordering it to pay 99 billion rubles ($3.4 billion) in tax arrears and penalties. Yukos estimated that it should have $1.1 billion to $1.2 billion in cash and equivalents as of June 30, up from $800 million. Yukos has appealed the tax claim, and the court has said any attempt to collect the back taxes or fines must wait until Yukos has its hearing. That case is scheduled to begin today. Yukos also has 30 days to appeal the decision upholding the tax claim, which was returned Wednesday by the Moscow Arbitration Court. The chief lawyer for Yukos, Dmitri Gololov, said the company would fight the arbitration ruling.

lead_paragraph: So far it's been a good season for Kemp's ridley sea turtles at Padre Island National Seashore, off the gulf coast of Texas. This time of year, the females of this endangered species come ashore to lay eggs, under the watchful eyes of the staff from the National Park Service's Sea Turtle Science and Recovery lab. There's a good chance they'll find even more nests this year than the old record of 38 in 2002, though that is still a far cry from the tens of thousands of turtles that used to nest on the gulf beaches farther south.

abstract: Moscow Arbitration Court upholds lower court ruling nullifying stock issue by Yukos to acquire Sibneft; formal control of Sibneft will revert to Millhouse Capital, company that manages assets of Russian billionaire Roman A Abramovich (S)
snippet: Moscow Arbitration Court upholds lower court ruling nullifying stock issue by Yukos to acquire Sibneft; formal control of Sibneft will revert to Millhouse Capital, company that manages assets of Russian billionaire Roman A Abramovich (S)
lead_paragraph: The Moscow Arbitration Court upheld a lower court ruling that nullified a stock issue used by Russia's largest oil company, Yukos, to acquire a rival, Sibneft, according to the news agency Interfax. Under the ruling, formal control of Sibneft would revert to Millhouse Capital, the company that manages the assets of the Russian billionaire Roman A. Abramovich. It was not clear if Yukos would appeal. Yukos has owned 92 percent of Sibneft on paper since October, when the deal was completed, though Yukos has not been able to establish operating control. Sibneft scrapped the merger after Yukos's founder, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, was jailed last October. As a result of the ruling, Millouse Capital will see its stake in Yukos fall to 9 percent from 26 percent.

abstract: World Business Briefing: S
snippet: World Business Briefing: S
lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group cut its 2002 oil and gas reserves for the fourth time, lopping 120 million more barrels off the number. The change comes as Shell prepares to refile its 2002 annual report on Friday after reducing its reserve levels by 20 percent in January. Shell's 2002 reserves now stand at 4.47 billion barrels, a 23 percent drop from the company's originally reported results. In a conference call, the chairman, Jeroen van der Veer, said the company's 2003 reserve replacement ratio, a measure of how quickly an oil company finds new resources as they are depleted, stands at 68 percent. Managing directors will not receive bonuses for 2003, a spokeswoman said during the call. Heather Timmons (NYT)

abstract: Op-Ed article by Anthony H Cordesman says Al Qaeda's two relatively small-scale attacks in month on soft targets in Saudi Arabia were successful because of American reaction, which was to panic and call for all Americans to leave country; says Al Qaeda's target was willingness of foreigners to stay in Saudi Arabia, as well as Saudi regime and its efforts to modernize country and rebuild ties to United States; says what United States should have done, but did not, was call for new Saudi security efforts, offer aid in counterterrorism, or try to fight back; says US must do everything it can to help Saudis and others defeat terrorism and improve protection of foreign workers and oil facilities (M)
snippet: Op-Ed article by Anthony H Cordesman says Al Qaeda's two relatively small-scale attacks in month on soft targets in Saudi Arabia were successful because of American reaction, which was to panic and call for all Americans to leave country; says Al ...
lead_paragraph: Al Qaeda carried out its most successful attack since 9/11 last weekend, and much of that success was a result of the American reaction. It was the second time in a month that the terrorists struck at a soft target in Saudi Arabia's petroleum industry. Twenty-two people -- Saudis, an American and other foreigners -- lost their lives, and this is truly tragic. But in the grand scheme of things, it was a small-scale attack, and should not have been treated as more. The terrorists did not strike at the Saudi petroleum industry; not a barrel of export capacity was lost.

The four were Gunner's Mate Brian W. Bressan, Technician Michael Sahlberg, Technician Clinton Comer (who was correctly identified) and Electrician David Benson. An e-mail message from Technician Sahlberg on Sept. 2 alerted The Times that the identifications were incorrect; this correction was delayed for verification of the correct identifications.

The Associated Press quoted a Lebanese woman, Orora Naoufal, who was taken hostage in her apartment, as saying that the gunmen released her when they learned of her nationality. They told her they were interested in harming only ''infidels'' and Westerners.

abstract: XTO Energy to purchase natural-gas and oil properties in New Mexico, Texas and five other states from ChevronTexaco for $1.1 billion in its largest acquisition ever (S)
snippet: XTO Energy to purchase natural-gas and oil properties in New Mexico, Texas and five other states from ChevronTexaco for $1.1 billion in its largest acquisition ever (S)
lead_paragraph: XTO Energy agreed to purchase natural-gas and oil properties in New Mexico, Texas and five other states from ChevronTexaco for $1.1 billion in its largest acquisition ever. The reserves will help XTO increase output by 30 percent this year, up from a previous estimate of 20 percent, the company said in a statement. XTO plans a share offering to help pay for a total of $1.8 billion in acquisitions this year, the chief executive, Bob Simpson, 56, said during a conference call with analysts and investors. XTO's new acquisitions will strengthen its presence in Louisiana, Oklahoma, New Mexico and the Permian Basin of West Texas. It will add properties in South Texas and a coal-bed methane project in the Rocky Mountains.

abstract: French oil group Total reports first quarter earnings of 2 billion euros ($2.4 billion), down 8 percent from 2003 period; chief financial officer Robert Castaigne says Total would consider buying stake in Russian oil company Sibneft if Sibneft ends its merger plan with Yukos (S)
snippet: French oil group Total reports first quarter earnings of 2 billion euros ($2.4 billion), down 8 percent from 2003 period; chief financial officer Robert Castaigne says Total would consider buying stake in Russian oil company Sibneft if Sibneft end...
lead_paragraph: The French oil group Total, which announced quarterly results, said it would consider buying a stake in the Russian oil company Sibneft if Sibneft were to end its merger plan with Yukos, another major Russian oil company. In a conference call to discuss the group's quarterly results, Total's chief financial officer, Robert Castaigne, responded to recent speculation that the two companies were discussing such a stake by saying that Sibneft would have to part ways with Yukos first. Total reported that its quarterly earnings were down 8 percent at 2 billion euros ($2.4 billion) for the first quarter of 2004, while sales dropped 2 percent to 28 billion euros ($33.8 billion). The company said its weaker results were caused by the weakness of the dollar relative to the euro and the rise of hydrocarbon prices, among other factors.

lead_paragraph: British Airways reported fourth-quarter pretax profit of £45 million ($80 million), in contrast to a loss of £200 million a year earlier. Helped by a cost-cutting program, the airline said its full-year income rose 70 percent, to £230 million ($407 million) before taxes. The chief executive, Rod Eddington, warned that rising fuel costs could affect future profits, and the company's shares fell 1 percent. Heather Timmons (NYT)

The company fired most of its finance department during a two-month strike last year, and that has led to delays in producing its financial results and accusations by former managers of irregularities.

lead_paragraph: The oil company BP reported $4.7 billion in profit for the first quarter, a 17 percent increase from the period a year earlier. The results included asset sales and credits of $1.18 billion. The company said it would split off more than half of its underperforming chemicals business in 2005, and might sell it in an initial public offering. Lord Browne, the chief executive, said that the book value of the business was about $7 billion. The company's revenue from petrochemicals was $16.1 billion in 2003, 7 percent of its total. Heather Timmons (NYT)

snippet: British Airways will add surcharge of 5 pounds ($8.89) to every round-trip fare on its British flights as result of rising price of oil; fares will increase by $4 per flight sector outside of Britain (S)
lead_paragraph: British Airways said it would add a surcharge of £5 ($8.89) to every round-trip fare on its British flights as a result of the rising price of oil. Outside Britain, fares will increase by $4 per flight sector. Airlines in the United States have tried to add fuel surcharges several times this year, but dropped them when their competitors did not match the fees. British Airways said it would review the charge on ''a regular basis with a view to adjusting it when appropriate.'' Heather Timmons (NYT)

abstract: China Petroleum and Chemical Corp says earnings in 2003 rose 32 percent, to 12.6 bilion yuan ($1.5 billion) but its profit falls short of analysts' forecasts; revenue increased to 443.14 billion yuan from 345.15 billion yuan in 2003; crude oil production rose 0.43 percent, to 271 million barrels and natural gas production rose 5 percent, to 187.7 billion cubic feet (S)
snippet: China Petroleum and Chemical Corp says earnings in 2003 rose 32 percent, to 12.6 bilion yuan ($1.5 billion) but its profit falls short of analysts' forecasts; revenue increased to 443.14 billion yuan from 345.15 billion yuan in 2003; crude oil pro...
lead_paragraph: China's largest oil refiner, the China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, said its earnings in 2003 rose 32 percent, to 12.6 billion yuan ($1.5 billion), but its profit fell short of analysts' forecasts. The company, known as Sinopec, said revenue increased to 443.14 billion yuan from 345.15 billion yuan in 2002. The company's average crude oil selling price rose to $27.56 a barrel in 2003 as a result of low inventories in the United States and war in Iraq, up from $22.42 a barrel a year earlier. Sinopec said its crude oil production rose 0.43 percent, to 271 million barrels in 2003, and its natural gas production rose 5 percent, to 187.7 billion cubic feet.

lead_paragraph: Schlumberger, the oil field services company, plans to raise as much as 689 million euros ($833 million) by selling its smart-card unit, Axalto Holding, in a share offering that began yesterday. The company offered 27.86 million Axalto shares, or 70 percent of the company, at 14.8 euros and 17.2 euros each. The number of shares may be increased to 100 percent of the stock, depending on investor demand, Axalto's chief executive, Olivier Piou, said at a presentation in Paris.

abstract: Clayton Williams Energy acquires Southwest Royalties for $187.8 million (S)
snippet: Clayton Williams Energy acquires Southwest Royalties for $187.8 million (S)
lead_paragraph: Clayton Williams Energy, which searches for and produces oil and natural gas, has agreed to buy Southwest Royalties, which is closely held, for $187.8 million to add its oil and gas reserves. Southwest Royalties is estimated to own 177 billion cubic feet of proven reserves as of March 31, and has an additional 53 billion cubic feet of probable reserves, Clayton Williams said. Clayton Williams, based in Midland, Tex., wants Southwest's reserves to complement its riskier exploration efforts, the company said. The acquisition is expected to close by May 21 and to add to earnings in 2004 and 2005.

lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said it would sell its 50 percent stake in an Angola offshore project to India's largest government-run oil and gas company, the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation, for about $600 million. Shell is under pressure to increase reserves after the company said in January that its proven oil and gas supplies were 20 percent lower than originally reported. abstract: *Thomas Friedman Op-Ed column welcomes Pres Bush's sober talk about Iraq situation but says country needs bipartisan commission to lay out proper course on Iraq and terrorism; offers own proposals, including huge expansion of US embassy libraries and scholarships for foreign students, Patriot Tax to fund military action and acknowledgement that war on terrorism is long-term effort requiring more than force (M)
snippet: *Thomas Friedman Op-Ed column welcomes Pres Bush's sober talk about Iraq situation but says country needs bipartisan commission to lay out proper course on Iraq and terrorism; offers own proposals, including huge expansion of US embassy libraries ...
lead_paragraph: I'm glad the president gave a sober talk about where we're going in Iraq and in confronting terrorism. But I can't say I found it reassuring. I still don't feel we have a broad, workable strategy. We currently have two national commissions looking backward -- one on how 9/11 happened, and another about why no W.M.D. were found in Iraq. Those are key questions. But what we really need is a bipartisan commission looking forward. I'd call it the National Commission for Doing Things Right. Its mandate would be simple: tell the country what U.S. policy would be if we were determined to do things right in confronting terrorism, no matter what the political costs -- so we don't have to have yet another commission looking backward two years from now. Here's what I'd like to see:

lead_paragraph: Alaska will allow oil and gas exploration in the Beaufort Sea next to the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge starting in October, Gov. Frank H. Murkowski said. abstract: Plains All American Pipeline, marketer of crude oil, says Texas attorney general is probing its purchase of Link Energy Co's oil pipeline operations on concern transaction will thwart competition (S)
snippet: Plains All American Pipeline, marketer of crude oil, says Texas attorney general is probing its purchase of Link Energy Co's oil pipeline operations on concern transaction will thwart competition (S)
lead_paragraph: Plains All American Pipeline, a marketer of crude oil, said yesterday that the Texas attorney general was investigating its purchase of Link Energy's oil pipeline operations on concern that the transaction would thwart competition. The state attorney general's office indicated that the investigation was prompted by complaints about the potential impact on competition in the Permian Basin in West Texas, Plains said in a regulatory filing. A spokesman for the attorney general declined to comment or to confirm the investigation. Plains bought 3,100 miles of crude oil pipelines from Link Energy, terminals able to store 3.4 million barrels of oil and 200 trucks for $273 million last week.

abstract: PetroChina Co posts 48 percent increase in profit for 2003, helped by sharp increase in average selling price of crude oil; earned 69.6 billion yuan for year (S)
snippet: PetroChina Co posts 48 percent increase in profit for 2003, helped by sharp increase in average selling price of crude oil; earned 69.6 billion yuan for year (S)
lead_paragraph: China's top oil and gas producer, the PetroChina Company, posted a 48 percent increase in profit for last year, helped by a sharp increase in the average selling price of crude oil. PetroChina said it earned 69.6 billion yuan for the year. ''The strong growth in China's economy and the jump in the oil price were our growth drivers in 2003,'' said PetroChina's president, Chen Geng. The company said all four of its divisions -- exploration and production, chemicals, refining, and natural gas and pipelines -- were profitable. PetroChina has not had profits simultaneously in all four divisions since it listed in April 2000.

Ramachandran, said. BP, Europe's largest oil company, announced last month that it was leaving the retail business in Malaysia and Singapore. abstract: Kerr-McGee Corp, which produces oil and natural gas, will cut spending on exploration by 14 percent in 2004 (S)
snippet: Kerr-McGee Corp, which produces oil and natural gas, will cut spending on exploration by 14 percent in 2004 (S)
lead_paragraph: The Kerr-McGee Corporation, which produces oil and natural gas, will cut spending on exploration by 14 percent in 2004. The company will spend $300 million this year on exploring for oil and gas, down from $350 million last year, David Hager, senior vice president for oil and gas exploration and production, said at an energy conference in Vail, Colo. The company's $7 billion oil and gas business accounts for more than 70 percent of total assets, Mr. Hager said. Kerr-McGee, based in Oklahoma City, has operations in Alaska, Wyoming, Colorado, the Gulf of Mexico, the North Sea, Brazil and China. Production ''growth is primarily focused on deepwater exploration,'' he said.

lead_paragraph: Petrofund Energy Trust, one of Canada's oldest oil and natural gas income trusts, agreed to buy the Ultima Energy Trust for about 446 million Canadian dollars ($341 million) to reduce the cost of borrowing money for acquisitions. Petrofund will pay 0.442 unit and 17 Canadian cents for each Ultima unit, the trusts, based in Calgary, Alberta, said in a statement. The acquisition will increase Petrofund's production to the equivalent of 37,133 barrels of oil a day and reduce interest costs, the trusts said. The expanded trust will have net debt of 231.7 million Canadian dollars. ''The larger size will improve Petrofund's financing ability and its ability to compete for future acquisitions,'' Chris Dutcher, Petrofund's director of business development, said. The acquisition would also help Petrofund comply with a provision of the federal budget proposed by the Canadian government last week that would limit foreign ownership of oil and gas trusts to about 49 percent, beginning in 2007, Mr. Dutcher said. About 66 percent of the units of Petrofund, which was created in 1988, are held by foreign investors, he said.

abstract: Marathon Oil Corp drops plans to build $1.7 billion energy complex south of Tijuana, Mex, after Baja California state government expropriates site; state officials say site does not meet land-use requirements for region (S)
snippet: Marathon Oil Corp drops plans to build $1.7 billion energy complex south of Tijuana, Mex, after Baja California state government expropriates site; state officials say site does not meet land-use requirements for region (S)
lead_paragraph: The Marathon Oil Corporation said that it was dropping plans to build a $1.7 billion energy complex south of Tijuana, Mexico, after the Baja California state government expropriated the site this weekend. State officials said the site did not meet land-use requirements for the region. Some nearby residents have opposed the project, saying it posed a safety risk. Marathon, based in Houston, planned to build a liquefied natural gas terminal, a power plant and a wastewater treatment operation in the area and had received approval from the federal government's Regulatory Energy Commission. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Britain's market regulator, the Financial Services Authority, is investigating Shell Transport and Trading, the British half of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the agency said. The announcement follows mid-March reports that the regulator is taking an informal look at the company, after Shell cut 20 percent from its proven reserve estimates in January. It is unusual for the agency to comment publicly on an investigation, and the regulator is speaking out because of the ''high levels of public interest and concern'' about Shell, an agency spokeswoman, Kate Burns, said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

abstract: United Nations Security Council unanimously approves investigation into oil-for-food program to be headed by former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul A Volcker; photo (S)
snippet: United Nations Security Council unanimously approves investigation into oil-for-food program to be headed by former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul A Volcker; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The Security Council unanimously backed an independent inquiry into the United Nations oil-for-food program, and the former Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, took charge of it, pledging ''a full, fair investigation, as conclusive as we can make it.'' After meeting with Secretary General Kofi Annan, Mr. Volcker, left, said the most important task was seeing if there was substance to charges of corruption involving United Nations officials. ''If there is substance, get it out there, get it out in a hurry and cauterize the wound,'' he said. Saddam Hussein is said to have pocketed more than $10 billion from the $67 billion program, created to devote Iraqi oil revenues to the purchase of food and other aid. Warren Hoge (NYT)

abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp posts $5.44 billion profit, highest first-quarter refining earnings in 13 years; net income fell to 83 cents per share from $7.04 billion, or $1.05 per share, year earlier (S)
snippet: Exxon Mobil Corp posts $5.44 billion profit, highest first-quarter refining earnings in 13 years; net income fell to 83 cents per share from $7.04 billion, or $1.05 per share, year earlier (S)
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil Corporation posted a $5.44 billion profit yesterday as record United States gasoline prices resulted in the highest first-quarter refining earnings in 13 years. Net income fell to 83 cents a share from $7.04 billion, or $1.05 a share, a year earlier, Exxon said. In the period a year earlier, Exxon, based in Irving, Tex., had $2.2 billion in gains from an accounting change and the sale of its stake in Ruhrgas. First-quarter sales rose 6 percent, to $67.6 billion. ''Earnings on the refining and marketing side of the business were significantly above expectations,'' said Tim Ghriskey, chief investment officer at Solaris Asset Management. ''Anybody who goes to the gas pump these days shouldn't be surprised.'' Earnings were 3 cents a share higher than the highest estimate from 19 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial.

abstract: Standard & Poor's and Moody's cut debt ratings on Russian oil company Yukos, citing concerns that company may be forced into insolvency if it has to pay $3.5 billion tax penalty (S)
snippet: Standard & Poor's and Moody's cut debt ratings on Russian oil company Yukos, citing concerns that company may be forced into insolvency if it has to pay $3.5 billion tax penalty (S)
lead_paragraph: Two credit rating agencies, Standard & Poor's and Moody's, cut their debt ratings on the Russian oil company Yukos, citing concerns that the company may be forced into insolvency if the company has to pay a $3.5 billion tax penalty. The downgrade reflects ''concerns about the increasing risk of Yukos losing ownership rights over its crucial cash-generating subsidiaries and uncertainties regarding liquidity,'' an S.&P. analyst, Elena Anankina, said. ''If Yukos loses the tax case, the company may find itself under the threat of forced sale of core assets, insolvency procedures or effective nationalization of its assets,'' she said. The Russian tax ministry sued Yukos in December for back taxes, but Yukos has challenged the claim. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

abstract: World Business Briefing: Malay
snippet: World Business Briefing: Malay
lead_paragraph: The British oil giant BP plans to sell stakes in its Malaysian and Singapore retail gasoline business as part of a corporate realignment. BP will sell its 70 percent stake in its Malaysian retail unit, which runs 240 gasoline stations, said Rosli Hussin, BP's Malaysian director for corporate affairs. In addition, BP will sell 30 gasoline stations that it runs in Singapore. It is selling assets in some countries to focus on regions with potential for higher growth, like Russia. It made a $6.35 billion investment in Russia last year. The company is also planning to sell its liquefied petroleum gas business in Malaysia and Singapore. The remaining 30 percent in its Malaysian unit is held by Lembaga Tabung Angkatan Tentera, an armed forces trust fund. BP said it would keep its other Malaysian units including the manufacturing of chemicals and lubricants.

lead_paragraph: Though the recent spike in gasoline prices invites serious debate about America's long-term energy policy, President Bush and Senator John Kerry seem more interested in scoring quick political points. Mr. Kerry's campaign literature offers the makings of a broad energy strategy that would reduce the nation's reliance on fossil fuels -- and therefore on Persian Gulf oil. Yet the prospect of capitalizing on consumer anxieties has enticed the president and Mr. Kerry into useless finger-pointing.

lead_paragraph: OIL AND GAS DEVELOPMENT IN ALASKA Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton cleared a plan to open 8.8 million acres of Alaska's North Slope to oil and gas development. The plan will be used to manage a northwest part of the government's 23.5 million-acre National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska, which geologists believe may contain 6 billion to 13 billion barrels of oil. Environmentalists said the plan threatened the health of Arctic tundra, ponds and lakes that are home to wildlife and migratory birds.   (AP)

abstract: Some of reasons for jump in gas prices noted (S)
snippet: Some of reasons for jump in gas prices noted (S)
lead_paragraph: POLITICS partly explains today's gasoline prices. Turmoil in Venezuela and Nigeria have disrupted supplies. Iraq's exports are constrained by domestic violence and insecurity along its northern export pipeline route. More broadly, conflict in the Middle East and anxiety about terrorism are pushing up prices. Then there's OPEC, which last week announced a new production cut. Meanwhile, demand is growing more strongly than it has for several years. The No.1 reason is China, which is experiencing rapid economic growth.

abstract: Coast Guard finds bodies of four men about 100 miles off Texas coast; they are thought to have been among 10 people aboard Era Aviation helicopter lost over Gulf of Mexico on its way to oil drilling ship (S)

lead_paragraph: The bodies of four men thought to have been among 10 people aboard a helicopter lost over the Gulf of Mexico were found yesterday about 100 miles from the Texas coast, the Coast Guard said. A life jacket bearing the name of the air charter company, Era Aviation, was also found. The helicopter left Galveston Tuesday for an oil drilling ship 130 miles east of South Padre Island and at the time of its last radio transmission was more than halfway toward the vessel. Steve Barnes (NYT)

abstract: Yukos Oil takes another step to distance management of oil company from its principal shareholders in effort to fend off continued political attacks; company's directors oust Mikhail B Brudno, acting president of company's refining and marketing division, citing corporate government standards; Brudno owns 7 percent of holding company that houses financial empire of Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, former Yukos chief executive who stepped down after his arrest Oct 25; Khodorkovsky is in prison awaiting trial on charges of tax evasion, fraud and embezzlement; Brudno will be succeeded by Peter S Zolotarev; photo (M)
snippet: Yukos Oil takes another step to distance management of oil company from its principal shareholders in effort to fend off continued political attacks; company's directors oust Mikhail B Brudno, acting president of company's refining and marketing d...
lead_paragraph: The Yukos Oil company took another step to distance management of the oil company from its principal shareholders in an effort to fend off continued political attacks. The company's directors ousted Mikhail B. Brudno, left, acting president of the company's refining and marketing division, citing corporate governance standards. Mr. Brudno was recently put on a wanted list by Russia's prosecutor general's office. Mr. Brudno was the last large Yukos shareholder still actively helping to run the oil business. He owns 7 percent of a holding company that houses the financial empire of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former Yukos chief executive who stepped down after his arrest Oct. 25. Mr. Khodorkovsky is in prison awaiting trial on charges of tax evasion, fraud and embezzlement. Mr. Brudno will be succeeded by Peter S. Zolotarev, previously first vice president for economics and finance at the refining division. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

abstract: Leucadia Revises Takeover Bid for Pla

lead_paragraph: The Leucadia National Corporation revised its offer for Plains Resources to include preferred stock to counter an all-cash bid for the oil company from Plains's top two executives and Vulcan Capital. The offer of cash, newly issued notes and preferred stock values each Plains share at about $18.75, $18 at a minimum, Leucadia said in a letter to Plains Resources' directors. Plains, which is based in Houston, rejected an offer of cash and notes valued by Leucadia at $18.19 a share in favor of an all-cash offer from Vulcan Capital valued at $16.75. Leucadia said it reworked the offer to answer concerns raised by a special committee of the Plains board that reviewed the bids.

abstract: Valero Energy Corporation, a leading oil refiner, agrees to buy El Paso Corp's refinery in Aruba for $365 million (S)
snippet: Valero Energy Corporation, a leading oil refiner, agrees to buy El Paso Corp's refinery in Aruba for $365 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The Valero Energy Corporation, a leading oil refiner, agreed to buy the El Paso Corporation's refinery in Aruba for $365 million. Valero will also pay $100 million for related marine and bunker-fuel operations, and $250 million for working capital, the company said. The refinery can process 315,000 barrels of crude oil a day. Valero, based in San Antonio, has more than doubled the size of its refining network since 2001. The addition of the Aruba refinery might increase net income by about $80 million this year and $175 million in 2005, the chief executive, Bill Greehey, said in a statement.

abstract: State will pay to have spring water delivered to residents of Redwood, NY, and contribute up to $1.8 million towards cost of $7.3 million pipeline to deliver fresh water to town, whose groundwater is polluted by gasoline and oil from leaking commercial and residential tanks; photo (S)
snippet: State will pay to have spring water delivered to residents of Redwood, NY, and contribute up to $1.8 million towards cost of $7.3 million pipeline to deliver fresh water to town, whose groundwater is polluted by gasoline and oil from leaking comme...
lead_paragraph: Residents of this upstate hamlet, who have put up with discolored well water that smells like oil for more than 20 years, will have spring water delivered to them free until a seven-mile pipeline can be built to bring in fresh water from the St. Lawrence River. The New York State Environmental Protection and Spill Compensation Fund announced yesterday that it would pay for the bottled water and contribute up to $1.8 million toward the $7.3 million cost of the pipeline, expected to be completed by 2006. State officials said that for decades, gasoline and oil from leaking commercial and residential tanks spilled into the groundwater, eventually contaminating the wells of about half the 200 homes in Redwood, 23 miles north of Watertown. Starting in 1983, those homes were fitted with charcoal filters, paid for by the oil spill fund. Jeffrey Gordon, a spokesman for Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, above, whose office administers the fund, said the recent discovery of lead in the Redwood wells made financing the pipeline even more urgent. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

abstract: Varco International, which announced last week that it was quitting oil-rig fabrication business, is cutting 200 jobs because of decreasing sales; reports fourth-quarter net income fell 79 percent to $4.6 million from $21.4 million year earlier; sales fell 14 percent to $349.7 million from $354.5 millionyear ago (S)
snippet: Varco International, which announced last week that it was quitting oil-rig fabrication business, is cutting 200 jobs because of decreasing sales; reports fourth-quarter net income fell 79 percent to $4.6 million from $21.4 million year earlier; s...
lead_paragraph: Varco International, which announced last week that it was quitting the oil-rig fabrication business, said yesterday that it was cutting 200 jobs because of decreasing sales. Varco said it expected the job cuts at its drilling equipment sales group in Orange, Calif., and in Houston to be completed by the end of the second quarter. The company said it would have $5 million in expenses related to the reductions in the first half of 2004 and save $20 million a year. Varco reported that fourth-quarter net income fell 79 percent to $4.6 million, or 5 cents a share, from $21.4 million, or 22 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 14 percent to $349.7 million from $354.5 million a year earlier.

lead_paragraph: India announced a series of measures that would relax import duties and restrictions for several sectors of the economy in an attempt to increase exports. The government said it would eliminate duties on professional equipment for the services industry and on fuel for the manufacturing industry. Restrictions on gold and silver imports by jewelers and by bullion traders were also eased. The government hopes the measures help it meet a goal of a 12 percent increase in exports this year. Saritha Rai (NYT)

lead_paragraph: INVESTORS are punishing the Royal Dutch/Shell Group for making the worst of a good situation. abstract: The largest oil refiner in Asia, the China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, agreed to buy chemical plants and gasoline stations from its parent company for 4.58 billion yuan ($554 million) in cash and assets. Sinopec, as the refiner is known, is buying the plants and 1,023 filling stations from the China Petrochemical Corporation. In turn, Sinopec, which is based in Beijing, will sell its oil field services business to China Petrochemical for 1.75 billion yuan. In addition to the gasoline stations, Sinopec will buy businesses making raw materials for plastic bottles and synthetic fibers, and chemicals to speed oil refining.

abstract: Editorial contends that piracy on high seas is real and growing menace; holds that pirates are suspected of forging links with global terrorists, and greater effort is needed on part of governments and private shippers worldwide to secure their harbors, ships and sea lanes; notes that biggest problem is in Southeast Asia, particularly around Indonesia, where tankerloads of crude oil are regularly stolen; maintains that piracy has become one of globalization's most serious forms of organized crime and magnet for terrorists
snippet: Editorial contends that piracy on high seas is real and growing menace; holds that pirates are suspected of forging links with global terrorists, and greater effort is needed on part of governments and private shippers worldwide to secure their ha...
lead_paragraph: Piracy, these days, refers more often to digital miscreants who copy music and movies than to skull-and-crossbones derring-do on the high seas. But pirates of the old-fashioned variety, armed with automatic weapons, are not only a real and growing menace, they are also suspected of forging links with global terrorists. A greater effort is needed on the part of governments and private shippers worldwide to secure their harbors, ships and sea lanes.

lead_paragraph: It has been 15 years since the Exxon Valdez fetched up on a reef in Prince William Sound in Alaska, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil and dealing biological and economic shocks to the sound and its adjacent communities, none of which have fully recovered. In 1991, the ship's owner -- now Exxon Mobil -- reached a $900 million civil settlement with the federal government and Alaska. Its obligations to the thousands of fishermen and others who suffered from the spill remain unresolved. It is past time for the company to pay up and put the entire sorry episode behind it.

abstract: Gasoline Prices on Course To Reach Record Levels  Anyone who has not been shocked by the rapid climb in retail gasoline prices may want to brace for what is to come. The fear of disruptions in oil supplies and stricter environmental regulations are expected to push prices even higher this spring and summer.    A federal agency said that gasoline supplies declined by 800,000 barrels last month, to 5 percent below the five-year running average. Earlier in the month, the agency warned that gasoline prices might rise to a nationwide average of $1.83 a gallon in April and $1.82 in May. Moreover, crude oil prices rose nearly 2 percent, to a 13-year high. [Page A1.]

abstract: Saddam Hussein's government systematically extracted billions of dollars in kickbacks from companies participating in United Nations program under which Iraq was permitted to sell oil to buy food and other relief goods; Taha Yassin Ramadan, vice president in August 2000, informed government ministers to tell companies involved in program to inflate their contracts 'by biggest percentage possible' and secretly transfer those amounts to Iraq's bank accounts in Jordan and United Arab Emirates; sanction-busting has long been open secret, but dimensions of corruption have only lately become clear; Iraqi Provisional Government has reviewed $8.7 billion in outstanding oil-for-food contracts and found that 70 pecent of suppliers had inflated their prices and agreed to pay 10 percent kickback; some companies balked at demands, but most accepted suggestion that they find trading company -- usually Russian or Arab -- to act as intermediary, deal with Iraq and make required kickback; Hussein also bestowed contracts and gifts on those who praised him, with frequent result that Iraq received shoddy, even useless, goods in return; photos of Iraqi documents (L)
snippet: Saddam Hussein's government systematically extracted billions of dollars in kickbacks from companies participating in United Nations program under which Iraq was permitted to sell oil to buy food and other relief goods; Taha Yassin Ramadan, vice p...
lead_paragraph: In its final years in power, Saddam Hussein's government systematically extracted billions of dollars in kickbacks from companies doing business with Iraq, funneling most of the illicit funds through a network of foreign bank accounts in violation of United Nations sanctions.

headline.main: Hussein's Regime Skimmed Billions From Aid Program
headline.print_headline: Hussein's Regime Skimmed Billions From Aid Program

abstract: Growth in Japan's Economy Surpasses All Expectations  The growth in the Japanese economy exceeded all expectations for the first quarter as a largely export-driven recovery broadened to include a pickup in consumer spending.    Japan's gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of 5.6 percent, after vigorous growth in the fourth quarter of 2003, when the economy increased at a 6.4 percent annual pace, the fastest expansion in 13 years. The most-recent figures show that Japanese consumers are also contributing to the recovery, which is nearly two years old. [Page C4.]

abstract: Coast Guard halts for night search for 18 sailors still missing after Bow Mariner, ethanol-laden tanker, exploded, burned and sank in frigid Atlantic waters off Virginia; says chances sailors are alive are slim; plucked six survivors from life raft in tense helicopter rescue; says at least three crewmen are known dead; officials say ethanol will dissipate in water and not pose environmental threat; tanker is owned by Singaporean unit of Norwegian firm Odfjell ASA; map; photos (M)
snippet: Coast Guard halts for night search for 18 sailors still missing after Bow Mariner, ethanol-laden tanker, exploded, burned and sank in frigid Atlantic waters off Virginia; says chances sailors are alive are slim; plucked six survivors from life raf...
lead_paragraph: Rescue helicopters and ships scoured the frigid Atlantic waters off Virginia on Sunday for 18 sailors whose ethanol-laden tanker ship exploded, burned and sank Saturday night. But Coast Guard officials said the chances of finding any of the crewmen alive were slim, and the search was stopped for the night.

abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    Leader of Iraqi Council Killed by Suicide Bomber  A suicide bomber killed the president of the Iraqi Governing Council and at least six other people at a checkpoint into the main headquarters for the American occupation forces in Iraq. Two American soldiers and five Iraqi civilians were wounded in the attack, the military said.   A1    American commanders said they had discovered an Iraqi artillery shell containing sarin, one of the deadly nerve agents that Saddam Hussein said he had destroyed before the war began last year.   A10    The American officer who was in charge of interrogations at Abu Ghraib prison told a senior Army investigator that intelligence officers sometimes instructed military police to force Iraqi detainees to strip naked and shackle them before they were questioned.   A1    Interrogators from military intelligence told guards at Abu Ghraib to deprive detainees of sleep or food and would strip detainees and make them sleep naked in their cells, but their orders stopped well short of the graphic abuse seen in the photos, according to testimony from guards and investigators.   A14    The Armed Services Committee said it would summon three senior military commanders to testify about the abuse of Iraqi prisoners.   A14    India Stock Market Crashes  Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born leader of the Indian National Congress party, will formally stake a claim to be India's next prime minister, party officials said, after the country's stock market recorded its biggest single-day fall amid concerns over the new government's approach to economic reforms.   A1    Gambia Rats Sniff Land Mines  The Gambian giant pouched rat may be as good a mine detector as man or nature has yet devised. They are abundant, cheap and easily transported. At three pounds, they are too light to detonate mines accidentally. They can sift the bouquet of land-mine aromas far better than any machine.   A1    NATIONAL   A16-21    Massachusetts Becomes First to Allow Gay Unions  Hundreds of gays and lesbians lined city halls from Boston to the Berkshires as Massachusetts became the first state in the nation to allow same-sex couples to marry.   A1    The mayor of New Paltz, who brought the same-sex marriage debate to New York state with solemnization ceremonies for 24 gay and lesbian couples in February, defended his action before the state Supreme Court in Kingston.   A21    Ruling on Access for Disabled  States that fail to make their courthouses accessible to people with disabilities can be sued under federal disability law, the Supreme Court ruled in a significant break from recent decisions that gave the states broad immunity from suit under various federal laws.   A16    Bush and Kerry in Kansas  President Bush and Senator John Kerry descended on Topeka to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Supreme Court ruling that ended school segregation.   A18    Parents Seek Visitation Rights  The parents of Terri Schiavo pleaded to once again be allowed unsupervised visits with their severely brain-damaged daughter, saying a police investigation had cleared them of accusations that they were responsible for marks found on her body on March 29.   A16    Lawsuit Over an Image  Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger's film production company filed a lawsuit against an Ohio toy maker, contending that the company's $19.95 Schwarzenegger bobblehead doll illegally exploits his image for commercial purposes.   A16    OBITUARIES   B8    June Taylor  The Emmy-winning choreographer whose routines on ''The Jackie Gleason Show'' brought the chorus line into the television age, she was 86.   B8    NEW YORK/REGION   B1-7    9/11 Panel to Question City's Lack of Preparation  Members of the commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks say current and former city officials in New York will be confronted at public hearings about why New York was not better prepared before Sept. 11 to deal with a catastrophic terrorist attack and why the city is still struggling to coordinate the disaster-response plans of its police officers and firefighters.   B1    Elite School Reduces Class Size  The principal of Stuyvesant High School, New York City's most sought-after specialized public school, has reduced the size of its incoming freshman class over the last two years even as education officials have been struggling with an acute shortage of seats in desirable high schools.   B3    $50 Million Gift to Mark Ruling  To mark the 50th anniversary of Brown v. Board of Education, a leading black Wall Street money manager and philanthropist announced that he will give $50 million to institutions and individuals working to improve race relations.   B2    FASHION   B9    ARTS   E1-9    SCIENCE TIMES   F1-8    Venus to Cross Face of Sun  The world is about to witness a rare spectacle that once launched expeditions to ideal vantage points around the globe and inspired millions of people to stare at the heavens. On June 8, people in the right places on Earth will be able to see Venus move across the face of the Sun in a kind of minieclipse that is visible twice every century or so. The last such occurrence, called a transit of Venus, was in 1882.   D1    Health & Fitness   F5    BUSINESS DAY   C1-14    Stocks Fall, Oil Prices Climb  Stock prices fell around the world, and oil prices continued to climb after the leader of the Iraqi governing council was killed by a suicide bomber. The three main American stock market gauges finished the day at new lows for the year.   C1    Congressional Democrats stepped up pressure on the Bush administration to ease gasoline prices by releasing oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, but administration officials plan to keep adding to the reserve until some time next year.   C11    Lucent Accused of Fraud  The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Lucent Technologies and nine former and current employees of fraudulently reporting nearly $1.2 billion in revenue.   C1    Business Digest   C1    World Business   W1    SPORTSTUESDAY   D1-7    EDITORIAL   A22-23    Editorials: Making votes count: voting machines for New York; more bad news from Baghdad; the global battle against AIDS: progress on pills, and opposition to condoms.    Columns: Paul Krugman, David Brooks.    Crossword   E2  TV Listings   E8  Public Lives   B2  Weather   D8

lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the economic impact of a $3.7 billion underground oil pipeline in Chad misstated the per capita income in the country. It is $220 a year, not $1,000.
